summaries.[BitPet] AR Game to Motivation Socialisa: This project develops an Augmented Reality game within the BitPet framework to motivate socialization and physical activity. It involves researching relevant theories, designing and developing a game concept using Unity for the front-end and a suitable back-end technology. The project culminates in a user evaluation to assess the game's effectiveness in promoting the desired behaviors. The BitPet team will provide technical support for this project.
summaries.AI and Game based learning (multiple pro: This project focuses on developing an AI-driven system to enhance math learning through educational games. It addresses the "cold start problem" by detecting difficult moments for students using wearable sensors and providing targeted support. The project involves designing and implementing a feedback tool, conducting usability studies, evaluating system effectiveness through larger user studies, and analyzing collected data. The ideal candidate should have a background in system design, basic machine learning, and strong programming skills in Python/Java.
summaries.Advancing Identity Security through AI: This project explores AI's role in enhancing identity security. It involves analyzing current identity verification methods, designing AI-powered systems for specific scenarios, and evaluating their effectiveness based on accuracy, false positives, and user satisfaction. The expected outcome is a fortified system against identity theft, leveraging AI to improve accuracy and efficiency in protecting personal information.
summaries.[ExerGames] Exercise Bike Game Developme: This project focuses on developing exergame concepts using an exercise bike as a primary game controller, supplemented by traditional button inputs. The research involves designing and implementing a prototype game in Unity and evaluating its impact on user enjoyment, motivation, and physical exertion through user testing. The expected outcome is an engaging exergame experience that promotes sustained physical activity.
summaries.[Lecture Games] AI Multi-player Classroo: This project focuses on developing an AI-enhanced multi-player learning game to improve student engagement and knowledge acquisition. It involves researching game-based learning and AI in games, designing and implementing a game concept, and evaluating its effectiveness through user testing. The expected outcome is a functional and engaging educational game that balances entertainment with learning.
summaries.[ExerGames] Play to get fit 2025/2026: This project explores exergames, aiming to create engaging and effective fitness games. It involves researching game-based motivation, designing and prototyping an exergame, and evaluating its effectiveness and player engagement. The project will balance fun gameplay with meaningful physical activity, using various technologies to develop a prototype. The expected outcome is a tested exergame prototype and insights into exergame design principles.
summaries.[ExerGames] Play to get fit 2024/2025: This project aims to develop novel exergame concepts and technologies, balancing fun gameplay with effective physical exercise. The project involves a theoretical study of exergames and motivational game mechanics, followed by the implementation of a prototype using various technologies. The final phase focuses on evaluating and testing the prototype. The expected outcome is a functional exergame prototype and insights into designing engaging and effective exergames.
summaries.AD - Visual Intelligence and accurate po: This project aims to develop a mobile application leveraging visual intelligence and precise positioning for road object condition assessment. The app will utilize the device's camera, CPos-corrected GPS, and AI models to geo-reference road objects. Expected outcomes include a functional application for road condition monitoring, with potential applications in HD-map creation, real-time image matching for localization, and data collection for neural rendering. The project is a collaboration between road authorities, SINTEF, and municipalities.
summaries.[BitPet] Empirical Study on the Physica: This project investigates the physical and social health impacts of BitPet, a location-based AR game promoting activity and social interaction. The research will employ questionnaires, interviews, observations, and in-game data analysis to assess BitPet's influence on physical and social activity, usability, and player experience. Expected outcomes include an evaluation of BitPet's health benefits, identification of key game elements, design guidelines for similar games, and potential extensions to exergaming theories.
summaries.A computer game to teach EU AI Act for t: This project explores the design and development of an educational computer game to teach the EU AI Act to healthcare professionals. Applying the design science research method, the project will create a game prototype and a methodology for designing such games. The game will be piloted and evaluated by healthcare stakeholders. Expected outcomes include a functional game prototype and a documented methodology for creating educational games on complex regulations like the EU AI Act.
summaries.[BitPet] AI Integration in a Location-B: This project investigates AI's role in enhancing BitPet, a location-based AR game promoting socialization and physical activity. The research involves studying AR, location-based innovation, and AI in gaming. Development focuses on implementing AI-driven features in Unity to improve gameplay and user experience, with both front-end and back-end components. Real-user testing will evaluate the effectiveness of AI enhancements. Expected outcomes include a refined, AI-enhanced game and insights into AI's impact on AR game engagement.
summaries.3D visualization of ship-breaking status: This project aims to improve safety in ship-breaking by developing 3D visualizations of ship status and worker locations. The research involves understanding worker distribution in shipyards, designing and prototyping 3D visualizations, and gathering user feedback. The project is part of the SHEREC project, utilizing provided 3D models and support from project partners. The expected outcome is a visualization tool that enhances safety by providing workers with awareness of the ship-breaking status and the presence of nearby personnel.
summaries.3D oriented data augmentation for Deep O: This project explores 3D-oriented data augmentation techniques for deep object detection in marine environments. It aims to improve the realism of synthetic data by incorporating depth information extracted from images or videos using deep neural networks or motion stereo. The project will simulate weather conditions like fog, rain, and snow using physics-based modeling or deep learning. The performance of object detectors trained on 3D augmented data will be benchmarked against real-world data. Expected outcomes include refined augmentation methods, realistic synthetic weather effects, and potentially synthetic video generation.
summaries.[ExerGames] Multi-player pedal-game 2024: This project focuses on developing a multi-player exergame in Unity, controlled by an exercise bike and buttons. The research involves exploring existing exergames, designing and implementing a prototype, and providing feedback on the exergame framework's API. The expected outcome is a fun, engaging game that promotes physical exercise, evaluated through user experiments. Experience with Unity is required for this group project.
summaries.Agentic AI security vulnerabilities iden: This project investigates security vulnerabilities in Agentic AI systems, which utilize LLMs and other agents for complex tasks. The research will employ systematic literature reviews and design science to identify vulnerabilities and develop mitigation strategies. Expected outcomes include approaches and prototypes for identifying and mitigating Agentic AI risks, requiring strong coding skills and knowledge in AI and cybersecurity.
summaries.AI - NeRF and Gaussian splats for mobili: This project explores using Neural Radiance Fields (NeRF) and Gaussian splatting to create realistic digital twins for mobility applications, particularly autonomous vehicles in Nordic environments. The research involves generating local environments from autonomous platform data, potentially incorporating dynamic elements like vehicles and pedestrians. It also considers underwater NeRFs. The project aims to enhance an existing digital twin of Gløshaugen, import it into Nvidia Omniverse for autonomous vehicle training, and visualize it in VR/AR using Nvidia CloudXR to simulate driving conditions.
summaries.AI computer vision for Open Discovery o: This project explores AI computer vision for open discovery in educational AR, using OpenAI's CLIP or YOLOv5 to detect real-world objects from user photos. The goal is to design an architecture for object detection and similarity search, assess its feasibility, and investigate usage scenarios like visual search and environment tagging. The project aims to interface with MirageXR to enable AR learning content discovery based on the user's physical surroundings, tested on devices like Apple Vision Pro and HoloLens 2.
summaries.A shift from old-school to cutting-edge: This project explores using decentralized technology, specifically a user-owned health wallet platform, to improve homecare services in Trondheim municipality. The research will involve stakeholder interviews, development of a proof-of-concept web and mobile application, and a mixed-methods evaluation comparing the decentralized approach to traditional systems. Key evaluation criteria include user-centric data ownership, data privacy and security, operational efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and user satisfaction levels. The expected outcome is a more efficient, transparent, and patient-centric homecare service model.
summaries.A game engine based simulator framework: This project aims to develop a game engine-based simulation framework for the Otter USV, integrated with ROS2. The project involves selecting a suitable game engine (Unreal Engine 5 or Unity), establishing ROS2 communication, and simulating the Otter USV with SeaSight Camera and Lidar systems. The framework will transfer sensor data to ROS2 topics for analysis and comparison with real-world data. Expected outcomes include a functional simulation environment for USV testing, validation, and potential use in data augmentation for machine learning.
summaries.AD (Autonomous Driving), AI/ML/DL and Co: This project explores autonomous driving (AD) using AI/ML/DL and computer vision, leveraging NAP-lab's research platform. It investigates end-to-end (imitation/reinforcement learning) and modular AD approaches (mapping, perception, planning, control) using NVIDIA DRIVE and ROS. Research includes simulated environments (CARLA, NVIDIA DRIVE Sim, NeRF), domain adaptation, and AD as a mobile sensor platform in challenging Nordic conditions. Point cloud processing for object detection/tracking and remote AV control via 5G are also explored. The goal is to advance NAP-lab's AD project through motivated student contributions.
summaries.AI-Driven Diagnostic Assistant for Medic: This project focuses on developing an AI-driven web application to enhance medical diagnostics. The research involves utilizing AI technologies to analyze medical data from scintigraphy images, blood analysis, and anamnesis. The expected outcome is a diagnostic assistant that provides data visualizations and complex diagnostics, ultimately improving patient outcomes and streamlining healthcare professionals' work. Students can choose to focus on one or more of the data analysis areas.
summaries.Artificial Intelligence in the Healthcar: This project investigates the impact of Artificial Intelligence (AI) on healthcare professionals' work. It aims to understand how AI technologies, such as machine learning in radiology, are altering the roles of doctors, nurses, and administrative staff. The research will explore both the positive and negative consequences experienced by healthcare practitioners due to the increasing integration of AI in their daily tasks. The expected outcome is a comprehensive understanding of the evolving nature of work in healthcare due to AI.
summaries.AI in the classroom: Actively learning f: This project explores using AI to analyze student feedback during lectures to improve teaching. It employs sentiment analysis, natural language processing, and machine learning on open-text student responses. The goal is to extract actionable insights from student perceptions, informing strategies to enhance teaching and learning effectiveness. The expected outcome is a system that transforms raw feedback into tangible improvements in educational practices.
summaries.Architecture-based reliability evaluatio: This project explores applying architecture-based reliability evaluation methods, like Fault Trees, to machine learning pipelines. The goal is to adapt existing techniques for traditional systems to the ML context, enabling comparison of different ML architectures based on fault tolerance. The project involves a literature review, defining/extending a method for deriving reliability models from ML pipeline diagrams (e.g., using Netron), and adapting the method to a semester-long task. Expected outcomes include a method for evaluating ML pipeline reliability based on architectural diagrams. Technologies used include Python, TensorBoard, and Netron.
summaries.AI for Mobile Robotics Systems: Let us: This master's project focuses on applying AI to mobile robotics, offering flexibility to define a project based on individual interests within specified areas. Key research areas include certifiable AI for safety-critical systems, efficient deep learning architectures, computer vision in challenging conditions, and machine learning for planning and control in mobile systems. The project may involve building prototypes for mobile systems like cars, ships, and drones, potentially within the context of autonomous racing. Collaboration with industry partners offers opportunities for industry-relevant topics such as AI qualification and drone-based inspection.
summaries.AI-Based gaze-aware feedback system for: This project focuses on developing and evaluating an AI-based gaze-aware feedback system to assist students in real-time during programming. It integrates eye-tracking data and IDE logs to provide targeted help. The project involves designing and implementing the tool, conducting usability testing, and performing a larger user study to assess its effectiveness. The expected outcome is an efficient and effective system for supporting students in programming, validated through user studies and data analysis. Python programming skills and a background in machine learning are required.
summaries.AI for sustainable business models: This project explores the relationship between Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Sustainable Business Models (SBMs). It investigates how companies can leverage AI for SBM implementation and conceptualizes the connection between AI, SBM, and competitive performance. The research aims to address the gap in understanding the mechanisms by which AI enables sustainable transitions, providing insights for firms to accelerate their adoption of SBMs and achieve a triple bottom line.
summaries.Automated indoor tasks assisted by drone: This project focuses on developing a system for autonomous drone navigation and task execution within indoor environments. Key components include dynamic environment mapping, collision-free navigation, mission planning/scheduling, and fleet management with self-monitoring for return to base. Example tasks involve inspection with image capture and environmental measurements (temperature, humidity, CO2). The project involves literature review, prototype design/implementation, and user testing.
summaries.AI for knowledge work – how to succeed i: This project explores the practical application of AI in knowledge work, focusing on how AI tools can effectively support various knowledge work practices. It begins with a literature review and may extend to an empirical study, potentially involving DNV. The research aims to understand the alignment of AI tools with specific knowledge work types, with the goal of identifying factors for successful AI implementation in industries like fisheries, police, and the justice system. The project is in collaboration with SINTEF Digital.
summaries.AI for understanding marine ecosystems b: This project proposes using AI to analyze underwater acoustic data for understanding marine ecosystems. It focuses on developing classification and analysis models for large acoustic data streams, incorporating data from ocean observatories. The research aims to address challenges related to variability, sparsity, and noise in underwater sounds to identify and classify biophony and anthrophony. The expected outcome is a more effective understanding of marine ecosystems through improved analysis of underwater acoustic data.
summaries.Artificial Intelligence and pair program: This project explores using AI to predict pair programming performance by analyzing data from eye-tracking, EEG, heart rate, and facial expressions. Students will collect data during pair programming sessions, develop prediction algorithms based on interaction features, and compare algorithm performance. The expected outcome is a model that identifies key factors contributing to successful pair programming. The project requires a background in machine learning/deep learning and Python programming skills.
summaries.AI-lab pitched projects - Master-project: This project involves exploring various AI-lab pitched projects, including football analytics using video analysis, medical image analysis for AAA surgery optimization and brain segmentation, and Kartverket's projects on LiDAR point cloud classification, GNSS quality prediction, and point cloud streaming. Additional projects focus on monitoring nature loss with satellite data and AI (NINA), developing digital health twins (MIA Health), predicting fish locations (Catchwise), and monocular depth estimation for unmanned surface vessels (Maritime Robotics). The expected outcomes include AI-driven solutions for diverse applications, enhanced data analysis, and improved decision-making in respective fields.
summaries.Artificial Intelligence and Biometrics i: This project explores AI-driven educational tools using biometric data (eye-tracking, EEG, heart rate, etc.) to enhance student learning. The research involves collecting and analyzing multi-modal biometric data to predict student behavior and performance. The expected outcome is the development of AI solutions that personalize and improve learning experiences. Requires background in system design, machine learning, and programming skills in Python/Java.
summaries.Artificial Intelligence in Business: Unc: This project investigates the challenges and obstacles hindering the adoption of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in businesses. It will explore technological, organizational, and human factors that impede successful AI implementation. The research will involve data collection and analysis in collaboration with the Big Data Observatory, aiming to uncover practical insights into overcoming these challenges and facilitating effective AI integration in business environments.
summaries.AI4TEE - Generative/diffusion models for: This project explores AI-driven solutions for automating tool and landmark localization in cardiac ultrasound imaging, crucial for improving accuracy and patient safety during cardiac interventions. It investigates generative/diffusion models for image denoising and multi-modal image synthesis, AI for aortic valve detection, 3D segmentation of valves using U-Net or advanced architectures, and 3D tracking of structures using visual transformer-based architectures. Expected outcomes include enhanced image quality, automated anatomical landmark detection, and improved 3D segmentation and tracking capabilities in echocardiographic data.
summaries.AI4Pathology - Digital pathology, self s: This project explores AI applications in digital pathology for lung cancer staging using whole slide imaging (WSI). It focuses on developing machine learning techniques for automatic WSI assessment, including tumor segmentation using modern architectures and self-supervised learning for patch-based classification. The research aims to create novel clinical applications in collaboration with St Olavs Hospital and Levanger Hospital, potentially improving lung cancer diagnosis and prognostication.
summaries.AI-based Environment Perception for Unde: This project explores AI-based environment perception for autonomous underwater snake robots, focusing on computer vision techniques to address challenges like limited visibility and visual clutter. It aims to create a dynamic, situation-dependent model of the robot's surroundings and estimate its ego-motion. The project will evaluate classical and modern machine learning/deep learning methods to determine their suitability for underwater environments with limited visibility. The expected outcome is an empirical assessment of different computer vision approaches for underwater robot navigation.
summaries.Architecture-based modeling of security: This project explores architecture-based modeling techniques for security aspects in evolving software systems. It focuses on representing security concerns at the architectural level to facilitate security assessment. The research will investigate how these models can adapt to system evolution, enabling continuous security evaluation and identification of potential vulnerabilities throughout the software lifecycle. Expected outcomes include a modeling approach and evaluation of its effectiveness in identifying security risks in evolving systems.
summaries.AI-based Fair Recruitment Systems: This project investigates fair decision-making in AI-based hiring systems, focusing on the automated extraction of feature importance weights from recruitment data. It aims to compare these automatically derived weights with human-provided weights to ensure objectivity and consistency. The research will utilize machine learning techniques, potentially including K-Nearest Neighbors, and regression evaluation metrics (MAE, MSE, RMSE). Expected outcomes include insights into aligning AI-driven hiring with human values and contributing to the BIAS project's goal of mitigating bias in AI recruitment.
summaries.Applying NorLLM to enrich knowledge grap: This project explores using the Norwegian large language model (NorLLM) to enrich a knowledge graph representing Trondheim Kommune's public sector data. The goal is to improve the discovery of duplicate services/descriptions and quality articles, and to enable Norwegian language queries. The project involves literature review, semantic deduplication research using NorLLM, evaluation of different NorLLM models against non-Norwegian LLMs, and implementation of a suitable query method. The expected outcome is an enhanced knowledge graph with improved search capabilities using NorLLM for synonym/hypernym expansion.
summaries.Classroom interaction tools: This project investigates methods for enhancing interactivity in large classrooms, focusing on activities like group work, discussions, quizzes, and practical exercises. The research involves literature review, user testing, and data analysis, potentially requiring the development of data processing scripts and visualizations. The expected outcome is a set of findings and conclusions regarding effective classroom interaction strategies.
summaries.Chop my Chip! Dynamic Compilation Target: This project explores dynamic compilation targets within the LLVM compiler for hardware-software codesign using RISC-V. The goal is to enable rapid exploration of custom ISA extensions for domain-specific accelerators (e.g., autonomous driving, cryptography). The project aims to allow the compiler to recompile programs for various ISA variations and assess performance impact. It requires C/C++ programming, familiarity with CMake, Git, and LLVM, and involves collaboration with the University of Bologna and Politecnico di Milano.
summaries.Classifying animals in the wild: This project proposes developing deep learning models to classify animals and their surrounding backgrounds in wild, complex environments. Utilizing datasets like Elephant Expedition, Snapshot Wisconsin, Snapshot Serengeti, Camera catalog, and the Norwegian wildlife dataset, the research will focus on accurately labeling foreground animals (e.g., elk, rabbit, deer) and background elements (e.g., snow, grass, trees). The expected outcome is a robust classification system capable of handling challenges like varying environmental conditions and partially captured animals.
summaries.Automated indoor tasks assisted by rover: This project focuses on developing a system for rover-like robots to autonomously navigate indoor environments and perform tasks. Key components include dynamic mapping, collision-free navigation, mission planning/scheduling, fleet management, and self-monitoring for battery management. Example tasks include area inspection with photo capture and environmental measurements (temperature, humidity, CO2). The project involves literature review, prototype design/implementation, and user testing.
summaries.Collaborative Games for IT and Sustainab: This project explores using collaborative games to educate students on the impact of IT on sustainability and the UN Sustainable Development Goals. The project involves designing, prototyping, and evaluating a game. Students can choose specific sustainability goals, game genres, and technologies. Building upon existing work, the project aims to increase awareness of IT's role in achieving sustainability.
summaries.Characterization of marine detectors in: This project aims to characterize the performance of a multi-modal marine object detector (video, radar, Lidar) using statistical methods for system simulation. It focuses on abstracting the detector's input-output relationship under varying operational conditions (weather, visibility) without delving into specific sensor data processing algorithms. The goal is to create a representative sensor model for use in complex system simulations, building upon prior research and in collaboration with DNV.
summaries.Automated scanning tool for Kubernetes: This project focuses on developing an automated scanning tool for Kubernetes environments at Norsk Helsenett, ensuring compliance with predefined best practices. The tool will assess configurations related to admin rights, RBAC policies, and network policies. The development will draw inspiration from existing tools like kube-bench, kube-hunter, and Popeye. The expected outcome is a customized scanning tool that enhances Kubernetes security and compliance.
summaries.Comparing gaze input methods with tradit: This project compares gaze-based input methods with traditional mouse input for common tasks like web browsing, email, writing, and code editing. It involves a literature review, user testing, and data analysis. Expected outcomes include performance comparisons between input methods and potentially the development of data processing scripts or visualizations. The project aims to provide insights into the usability and efficiency of gaze interaction.
summaries.Cities as Urban Living Labs: This project investigates Urban Living Labs (ULLs) as a method for citizen engagement in urban service design. It aims to establish a small-scale ULL, potentially focusing on citizen health and well-being (e.g., SWELL project). The project involves a literature review, selection of co-creation and data evaluation methodologies, identification of a specific ULL focus, ULL establishment, and validation. Expected outcomes include a functional ULL and insights into its effectiveness in engaging citizens and improving urban services.
summaries.City learning: This project explores how cities can learn and evolve to align with transformations like energy transitions and digitalization. Building on an existing theoretical model for city learning, the project aims to develop a practical tool (e.g., a card set or game) to support city stakeholders in their learning and evolution processes. The methodology includes reviewing existing solutions, iteratively designing and developing the tool, and validating its effectiveness. The expected outcome is a validated tool that cities can use to facilitate continuous learning and adaptation.
summaries.Constructing an AI-based, intelligent gr: This project focuses on developing an AI-based intelligent ground vehicle using the Agilex LIMO robot platform. The research will explore cooperative robot interaction in dense environments, emphasizing intelligent behavior and autonomy over speed. The project involves specifying a vehicle goal (e.g., collision-free navigation, package delivery), implementing an intelligent component like vision or human interaction capabilities, and addressing engineering challenges in communication, perception, behavior, or control. Expected outcomes include a functional mobile robot with demonstrated intelligent capabilities and a mid-scale simulation of multi-robot interaction.
summaries.Bærekraftsrapportering (sustainability r: This master's project investigates the challenges and solutions for collecting, processing, and reporting sustainability data to meet the EU's Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive (CSRD) requirements, focusing on scope 3 emissions. In collaboration with Aneo AS, the project will address the under-specification of "sustainability," relevant data identification, data compilation methods, and target audience relevance. The research aims to provide insights into how companies can effectively integrate sustainability into their reporting practices.
summaries.Autonomous Ferry -- Projects in AI-based: This project focuses on developing AI-based perception systems for autonomous passenger ferries in collaboration with Zeabuz. Research areas include AI motion planning, stereo vision, object detection in visual and infrared imagery (especially in adverse weather), automatic infrared image labeling, reinforcement learning for safety validation, and wake simulation for situational awareness. The expected outcome is the development and implementation of robust AI algorithms for environment perception and situation assessment in autonomous marine vessels.
summaries.Continuous software delivery utilising P: This project explores the adoption and effectiveness of open-source Platform-as-a-Service (PaaS) solutions (e.g., nais.io, radix.equinor.com) in facilitating continuous software delivery and cloud migration within IT organizations. It investigates the rationale behind using PaaS, the benefits of open-source PaaS projects, and the challenges organizations face when adopting these platforms. The research aims to determine how well these solutions support developers in deploying applications to the cloud and their overall impact on software delivery frequency.
summaries.Contextualising data on the OSDU data pl: This project explores contextualizing data within the OSDU data platform using Active Knowledge Models (AKM) and role-specific workspaces. It aims to improve dataset discovery and link analyses to source data, addressing challenges in the upstream oil and gas sector. The project involves literature review, AKM model creation, OSDU schema import, and exploration of smart contextualization algorithms. Expected outcomes include identifying datasets for specific roles/tasks and investigating how contextualized data can automate tasks, potentially enabling cross-industry knowledge transfer, in collaboration with Equinor.
summaries.Compilers for Differential Algebraic Equ: This project focuses on developing a compiler for Differential Algebraic Equations (DAEs) using MLIR to improve the scalability of equation-based modeling and simulation. The research involves creating a benchmark suite for compiler performance and implementing equation-manipulation algorithms. Expected outcomes include a compiler capable of efficiently translating declarative models into executable simulations, addressing the limitations of current translation algorithms in handling large state variables. The project involves collaboration with Politecnico di Milano.
summaries.Autonomous Driving (AD): NAP-lab related: This project explores various aspects of autonomous driving (AD) using visual intelligence (AI/CV) within the NAP-lab. Key areas include end-to-end AD, neural reconstruction for sim-to-real gap, TeleDrive, HD-maps/Digital Twins using NVIDIA Omniverse, control algorithms, crowdsourcing for map updates, and anonymization of camera data. The research utilizes a KIA e-Niro equipped with NVIDIA DRIVE AGX Orin, multiple sensors, and CARLA/NVIDIA DRIVE Sim. Expected outcomes involve advancements in AD algorithms, improved simulation fidelity, and contributions to digital road twins, potentially leading to publications and further PhD studies.
summaries.Biometrics and Neuro-conceptualization: This project investigates the brain's processing of visual conceptual models (UML, BPMN) using biometric data (heart rate, EEG, eye-tracking). It aims to bridge the gap between neuroscience, neuro-linguistics, and IT by examining model comprehension. The research involves a literature review and experiments to analyze how the brain processes these models, considering individual differences and optimal modeling approaches. Expected outcomes include insights into model comprehension and potential material for a scientific publication.
summaries.Compilers for Approximate Computing: This project explores compiler techniques for approximate computing, specifically precision tuning. It aims to optimize performance metrics like speed and energy consumption by modifying data types (e.g., reducing bit precision, using fixed-point numbers). The project involves code analysis, transformations, and verification using C/C++, CMake, and potentially LLVM-IR or MLIR. Expected outcomes include novel compiler optimizations for approximate computing and collaboration with international research teams.
summaries.Combining EEG and motion capture in imme: This project explores combining EEG and HPE-based motion tracking within a VR exergame for enhanced rehabilitation feedback. The research focuses on synchronizing EEG data, human pose estimation, and VR content using pipelines like NeuroPype or Timeflux via LabStreamingLayer. Expected outcomes include a functional system providing patients with real-time feedback on attention levels, movement intention, and cognitive load, potentially improving rehabilitation outcomes. The project utilizes Vizlab resources, including VR headsets and EEG equipment.
summaries.Data science - in practice: This project investigates the gap between data-driven data science techniques and their practical application in organizations. Focusing on empirical case studies within sectors like energy and healthcare, the research aims to understand the conditions necessary for effective data science implementation in consequential decision-making. A key area of focus is enhancing the accountability and explainability of algorithms (XAI). This project is part of the SFI NorwAI initiative.
summaries.Development and maintenance of IT-system: This project analyzes quantitative and qualitative data from recent surveys on IT system development and maintenance in Norwegian organizations, supplemented by a literature review. The research aims to identify mechanisms affecting resource utilization in information systems support. Expected outcomes include a report in English suitable for scientific publication, providing new insights into resource management within organizational IT.
summaries.Digital registrering av innemiljø og til: This project explores the application of indoor climate and presence sensor data collected on a university campus. It aims to identify valuable uses for this data, potentially in the context of the "Smart workplaces past Covid-19" research project in collaboration with Mazemap and CISCO, and the FME-ZEN Zero Emission Neighbourhood initiative. The research focuses on leveraging sensor data for smart building applications.
summaries.Effects of Interpreted Languages on Micr: This project investigates the microarchitectural performance impact of interpreted languages like Python and JavaScript, prevalent in cloud computing FaaS environments. It addresses the challenge of hardware treating program logic as data, leading to inefficient cache utilization and branch prediction. The project aims to develop a tool to track data and code within the cache, analyze front-end and back-end performance bottlenecks, and propose methods for efficient and energy-aware execution of interpreted workloads, ultimately optimizing cloud infrastructure performance.
summaries.Development of ´Learn and Earn/Learn to: This project proposes developing a Web3 gaming platform where players learn, earn, and create content. The platform will reward users with points exchangeable for digital assets, enabling competitive gameplay. Research will focus on architectural differences between traditional and Web3 multiplayer game development, user onboarding challenges, scalability issues, and security implications of public smart contracts. Expected outcomes include a functional gaming platform and insights into integrating Web3 technologies into gaming.
summaries.Digital Twins (DTs) for Health and Infra: This master's project explores the application of Digital Twins (DTs) for either self-management of health or decision support for road infrastructure. The research will focus on developing and implementing DT models within one of these two domains. The expected outcome is a functional DT prototype demonstrating improved management or decision-making capabilities in the chosen area.
summaries.Crowdsourcing using Geographical Informa: This project proposes developing a crowdsourcing GIS platform to enhance place knowledge through shared stories and experiences. It will leverage open-source GIS and explore the application of Large Language Models (LLMs) for content analysis. The project includes a literature review, prototype development, LLM integration, and prototype validation. The expected outcome is a functional prototype demonstrating the feasibility of using GIS and LLMs for crowdsourced place-based knowledge creation.
summaries.Define your own project in Visual Comput: This master's project allows students to define their own research topic within Visual Computing, contingent on their performance in related courses (TDT4195, TDT4230) and the suitability of their project proposal. The specific research area, technologies, and expected outcomes are dependent on the student-defined project.
summaries.Designing a next generation user identit: This project proposes developing a user-owned digital wallet platform leveraging Web 3.0 technologies like self-sovereign identity for secure storage and management of identity documents (diplomas, licenses). The platform will feature encryption, biometric authentication, and user-friendly interface for easy document access, sharing, and renewal reminders. The project involves stakeholder consultation, prototype development, pilot testing, and iterative refinement based on user feedback, aiming for wider adoption and integration with existing digital systems.
summaries.EduWallet: A Blockchain-Enabled Digital: EduWallet aims to transform university credit management using blockchain technology. The project integrates Blackboard and Inspera APIs for real-time synchronization of enrollments, grades, and assessment outcomes. Smart contracts will streamline enrollment and credit transfer processes. A token-based incentive system will reward academic achievements. The system will provide a real-time dashboard for students and secure, verifiable academic records for institutions and employers.
summaries.Development of functionality for request: This project focuses on developing a mobile feature for the Visma InSchool app to streamline substitute teacher requests and assignments. The project involves understanding current processes, designing a user-friendly interface, developing the feature using agile methodologies, rigorous testing, and seamless implementation. The expected outcome is an efficient, functional mobile feature that improves the substitute teacher assignment process. The students will gain experience in mobile development, UI design, teamwork, and project management.
summaries.Education in the era of generative AI: U: This project explores the potential of ChatGPT in education, focusing on its benefits and challenges in teaching and learning. Through a case study, the research will investigate how generative AI can be leveraged to improve educational practices. The expected outcome is to provide recommendations for the safe and constructive use of AI tools like ChatGPT to enhance education and support student learning.
summaries.Digital Technologies for “placemaking” a: This project explores how digital technologies can facilitate "placemaking" and "placekeeping" to improve public spaces and community wellbeing. It aims to identify and prototype a digital solution, potentially using Augmented Reality or digital storytelling, to foster emotional connections to places through shared experiences. The research will involve literature review, iterative design, and participatory methods with end-users to validate the solution's effectiveness in creating and maintaining meaningful places.
summaries.Design Thinking learning with Emerging T: This project explores enhancing design thinking learning for students (under 18) using emerging technologies and learning analytics. It involves extending an online learning tool with a dashboard to capture and analyze student interaction data (e.g., eye-tracking). The research includes a literature review, system implementation using Javascript, iterative testing, a user study to collect empirical data, and analysis to improve user experience. Expected outcomes include a functional system, analyzed data, and insights into how learning analytics can enhance design thinking education.
summaries.Digitalisering i olje og gass - IoT: This project explores the role of IoT and sensor-based information in remote, unmanned subsea oil and gas operations. It addresses the challenge of unreliable sensor data (temperature, pressure, seismicity, etc.) due to wear and calibration issues. The research aims to determine how new IT tools can enable better decision-making despite high data uncertainty in exploration, drilling, logging, and production phases. The expected outcome is a framework for leveraging unreliable sensor data for improved operational efficiency and safety.
summaries.Define your own topic in software and sy: This master's project explores software and system reliability, safety, and security. The research area is flexible, allowing students to define a specific topic of interest within the field. Potential areas include reliability modeling at the architecture level, formal methods like model checking, fault injection, and testing techniques. The expected outcome is a master's thesis demonstrating research and application of chosen reliability/safety/security methods.
summaries.Driving with NeRFs: Simulating sensor in: This project explores using Neural Radiance Fields (NeRFs) and 3D Gaussian Splatting to enhance the nuPlan simulator for autonomous driving. The research aims to enable closed-loop simulation with realistic sensor inputs, a current limitation of nuPlan. Key questions involve leveraging nuPlan's data to aid view synthesis, assessing the quality and speed of novel view generation, and evaluating the synthesized views' utility for training end-to-end driving systems. The expected outcome is a nuPlan simulator capable of generating on-the-fly camera inputs for more comprehensive autonomous driving system development and evaluation.
summaries.Diversity Equity and Inclusion (DEI) in: This project explores Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) practices within Norwegian software development. Using empirical software engineering methods, the research investigates how companies incorporate diversity into their organizations, projects, and products. Data will be collected through interviews, analysis of course materials, report/software analysis, and workshops with companies and students. The goal is to understand the impact of diversity on software development teams and to identify effective guidelines for promoting diversity in software development processes.
summaries.Design and Evaluation: A digital tool to: This project focuses on developing and evaluating a digital tool for children to self-report their emotions and learning during design thinking activities. The project involves creating a web-based tool, potentially extending EmoForm, using technologies like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and Python. The tool's effectiveness will be evaluated through user studies in real-world settings, collecting and analyzing data to understand its impact. The expected outcome is a functional and usable digital tool and a comprehensive evaluation of its effectiveness in capturing children's emotional experiences during learning.
summaries.Design and prototyping workshops as coll: This project explores in-person workshops as a collaborative learning method for sustainable cities education. It aims to identify effective combinations of activities like lectures, ideation, and prototyping to equip students with multidisciplinary skills for urban sustainability challenges. The research may involve literature reviews, case studies of existing workshops through observation and surveys, and the design of new workshop tools and methods. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how workshops can foster collaborative learning and skill development in the context of sustainable urban development.
summaries.Generativ kunstig intelligens i programm: This project explores the use of generative AI in programming, focusing on its impact on learning and software development. Potential research areas include developing AI-powered chatbots for programming education, using AI to evaluate code against learning outcomes, and exploring AI's role in assessment. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how generative AI can be leveraged to improve programming education and software development processes.
summaries.High quality interactive digital twins i: This project focuses on developing a VR environment for visualizing and interacting with digital twins, in collaboration with the Institute of Cybernetics. The research will explore the creation of high-quality, interactive VR representations of digital twins, using examples such as autonomous aquariums/greenhouses, soil movement experiments, and overload prevention in electric cables. The expected outcome is a functional VR environment that allows users to monitor, control, and interact with real-time data from these digital twins.
summaries.Fake News (Disinformation) Detection: This project explores methods for detecting fake news from online sources using machine learning, natural language processing, and semantic web technologies. The research aims to analyze news articles from various sources to efficiently distinguish between real and fake news. The expected outcome is an effective approach for fake news detection.
summaries.Exploring the black box of AI Governance: This project explores the development and deployment of AI governance practices within organizations. It investigates the factors considered when establishing these practices, their implementation methods, and their impact on business and project performance. The research aims to understand how AI governance influences business value, ethical compliance, and regulatory adherence in AI projects.
summaries.Emotions and well-being in Computing edu: This project investigates emotions and well-being in computing education. It begins with a literature review on the topic, followed by empirical data collection to understand student needs, potentially using IDI as a case study. Based on these findings, the project may involve designing a tool, such as a game, to improve emotion awareness in computing education. The specific focus and tool type can be tailored to the student's interests.
summaries.Health information systems in developing: This project investigates health information systems in developing countries, focusing on the DHIS2 initiative, an open-source platform enhancing health service reporting. Utilizing mobile technologies, the research involves empirical fieldwork in Africa or Asia to identify requirements for selected DHIS2 services. The goal is to contribute to the implementation and evolution of DHIS2 software, improving healthcare delivery in resource-limited settings. Collaboration with the University of Oslo's DHIS2 team is a key component.
summaries.Employee-driven digital transformation: This research investigates employee participation in digital transformation initiatives, analyzing successful and failed attempts to identify challenges and best practices. The project employs empirical qualitative research methods to analyze existing research and conduct studies within organizations undergoing digital transformation. Expected outcomes include a deeper understanding of employee involvement in digitalization and recommendations for improving future initiatives. The research will be conducted in Norwegian, with the thesis potentially written in English.
summaries.Evaluating the Role of Gamified Simulati: This project explores gamified simulations in Articulate Storyline 360 to improve learner motivation and retention. It will integrate AI for performance tracking and adaptive game mechanics to personalize learning. The research will evaluate the impact of these simulations on learner motivation, engagement, and retention rates in online education. Expected outcomes include insights into how gamification can enhance learning and address challenges in online education.
summaries.Enhancing Online Laboratory Simulations: This project develops AI-based analytics models to improve online STEM laboratory simulations. It tracks learner interactions within Articulate Storyline 360 simulations to provide insights into engagement, skill acquisition, and performance. The goal is to inform real-time interventions and instructional design, ultimately enhancing student outcomes in STEM education.
summaries.Git dashboard: This project aims to develop a Git dashboard for educational settings, providing instructors with an overview of student projects. The dashboard will aggregate data from Git via API and generate insights through static/dynamic analysis. The expected outcome is a tool that allows instructors to efficiently monitor and compare the progress and status of multiple student projects, building upon previous related projects.
summaries.Ethical aspects of AI/recommender system: This project explores the ethical challenges of AI and recommender systems, focusing on privacy, fairness, and bias from a technical perspective. It aims to define these ethical concepts as mathematical models, implement them within AI systems, and evaluate the success of these approaches. The project will involve analyzing and mitigating bias and discrimination in AI, with a specific focus on recommender systems. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how to develop AI systems that treat everyone equally and fairly.
summaries.Human-Centered AI for Responsible Digita: This project explores human-centered AI within digital transformation, focusing on aligning AI systems with human values and societal well-being while achieving business value. Research can be tailored to organizational strategy, user interaction, technical design, or policy-making within sectors like healthcare or education, and technologies like machine learning or IoT. Methods include quantitative surveys, qualitative interviews, case studies, or design science. Expected outcomes include insights into stakeholder engagement, policy implications, and innovative technical designs for responsible AI implementation.
summaries.FlexEEG decoding of hand movement intent: This project aims to decode hand movement intentions from low-density EEG signals using source reconstruction and machine/deep learning algorithms. EEG data will be recorded from participants, analyzed, and used to build offline/online classifiers. The decoded movements will be integrated into software games, potentially for neurorehabilitation applications. The research will lay the groundwork for wearable EEG-based solutions.
summaries.Fighting Bias in Large Language Models: This project investigates and mitigates demographic biases in large language models, a critical area in current AI research. The project focuses on improving bias identification, quantification, and de-biasing methods. It aims to contribute to fair representation in language models by exploring unbiased datasets and refining learning algorithms. Expected outcomes include novel approaches to defining and reducing bias, leading to more equitable and inclusive language models.
summaries.Eye-tracking and training novice program: This project explores using eye-tracking and dialogue to improve novice programmer debugging skills. The research involves developing a gaze-enabled feedback tool, conducting usability testing, and performing a larger user study to evaluate the system's effectiveness. The expected outcome is a system that leverages expert gaze and dialogue to guide novices in identifying and correcting bugs. The project requires strong programming skills in Python/Java and a background in system design.
summaries.Game for reflection on ethical aspects o: This project focuses on developing a mobile game to promote reflection and discussion on ethical issues related to IT tools. Addressing concerns like algorithmic bias, data privacy, and addictive design, the game will be used in workshops and courses. The project builds upon previous work in teaching sustainability to computer science students, aiming to create an engaging tool for ethical awareness. Expected outcomes include a functional game and an evaluation of its effectiveness in facilitating ethical discussions.
summaries.Efficient assembly of software MVPs thro: This project aims to reduce MVP development time by enabling the reuse of existing services and components. The research will focus on abstracting customization patterns and variability aspects to develop a prototype tool. This tool will allow users to customize and assemble components from a design-time view (e.g., Figma) and import services. The expected outcome is a proof-of-concept tool and an analysis of methodologies for service and component reuse.
summaries.Empowering Children’s STEM Learning thro: This project explores using Motion-Based Technology (MBT) and GenAI to enhance children's STEM learning. It involves literature review, defining adaptive learning models, and utilizing Multimodal LLMs. The project aims to identify MBT aspects that support children's math learning, develop practical functionalities and interfaces, and evaluate/refine these through experimentation. Requires a background in data science, LLM integration, and strong programming skills in Python, C#, or JavaScript. Expected outcomes include a refined understanding of how MBT and GenAI can improve children's STEM education.
summaries.Flexible data visualization in a VR envi: This project aims to improve visuospatial neglect assessment using VR and eye-tracking. It involves developing flexible data visualization tools within a custom VR environment. The project will use Python to generate gaze data plots from VR tests and display them in the VR environment. It will classify gaze data into fixations and saccades, providing relevant statistical information to clinicians, visualized in an easily understandable manner. This work collaborates with the Department of Acquired Brain Injury, St. Olav's Hospital.
summaries.Enterprise Architectures for learning an: This project explores using Enterprise Architecture (EA) to facilitate knowledge transfer and learning between sustainable cities. It aims to enhance EA models to capture and replicate successful ICT ecosystems across different urban environments. The project involves a literature review, developing a prototype EA model, and validating its effectiveness in supporting knowledge transfer. The expected outcome is an improved EA model that promotes the adoption of sustainable solutions in cities by enabling effective learning from other cities.
summaries.Learning programming: This project explores how teachers' approaches to programming education are influenced by students' diverse learning prerequisites. It will investigate existing literature on factors affecting students' ability to learn programming, methods for adapting instruction to accommodate varying prerequisites, and teachers' awareness of these considerations. The expected outcome is a deeper understanding of the interplay between student prerequisites, teaching strategies, and teacher awareness in programming education.
summaries.Learning about AI in schools: This project investigates the current state of AI education in secondary schools through a literature review. It then focuses on designing an engaging and playful intervention for introducing AI concepts to students, emphasizing responsible and sustainable AI practices. The expected outcome is a practical intervention model for AI education in schools.
summaries.Machine learning-based prediction of rev: This project aims to develop a machine learning model to predict revenue for actors in a Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) ecosystem. By leveraging data on travel patterns, demographics, weather, and parking, the model will forecast ticket sales. The research will utilize data from the MaaSeKopp project and open data sources. The expected outcome is a tool that helps transport service providers assess the economic viability of joining a MaaS platform.
summaries.Integrating AI Chatbots into Articulate: This project explores integrating AI chatbots into Articulate Storyline 360 simulations to provide real-time learning scaffolding. The research will analyze the chatbots' effectiveness in addressing learner challenges and improving learning outcomes. The study aims to understand how conversational AI can personalize and enhance online learning experiences by analyzing learner interactions within the simulations.
summaries.Let the LIMO floor robot solve interesti: This project focuses on developing advanced AI capabilities for the AgileX LIMO floor robot, which is equipped with stereo cameras, LiDAR, and a Jetson Nano GPU. Building upon existing environment mapping and path planning foundations, the project aims to tackle new AI challenges such as object seeking, visitor recognition and greeting, or multi-robot interaction. Students can also propose their own AI robotics tasks, potentially incorporating speech interaction. The expected outcome is a LIMO robot capable of performing complex autonomous tasks within the AI Lab environment.
summaries.Investigations on Situation Awareness Sy: This project investigates AI-related aspects of a Situation Awareness System for an autonomous ferry in collaboration with Zeabuz. Building upon prior work, the research focuses on processing sensor data to create a dynamic environmental representation for safe navigation, collision avoidance, and complex maneuvers like docking. The project allows for specialization in machine learning or statistical model-based methods, depending on the student's interests and expertise. Expected outcomes include advancements in AI-driven situation awareness for autonomous maritime systems.
summaries.ICT for Health & Well-being in Built Env: This project investigates the role of Information and Communication Technology (ICT) in promoting health and well-being within sustainable built environments, aligned with the SWELL project. It involves literature reviews on ICT's impact on health in buildings and relevant interactive digital technologies. The core task is to design and prototype a solution that engages building users, followed by a thorough evaluation of the prototype's effectiveness. The expected outcome is a functional prototype and insights into leveraging ICT for healthier, more sustainable built environments.
summaries.Large-scale agile software develpment: This project investigates the adaptation and combination of agile and traditional practices in large-scale software development. It will explore first and second-generation large-scale agile methods like SAFe, LeSS, and the Spotify model. The project will begin with a literature review and may extend to an empirical study. The research can leverage material from the Agile 2.0 competence-building project with industry partners. Expected outcomes include insights into effective large-scale agile practices and their application in industrial settings.
summaries.Interoperability of Learning Systems: This project investigates learning system interoperability using xAPI and LTI standards to integrate data from platforms like FS, Canvas, and Sikt within the Norwegian educational ecosystem. The goal is to develop a prototype system that accesses and aggregates learning activity data via APIs, creating a dashboard for visualizing cross-system learning data. The project involves literature review, system architecture design, implementation of data access modules, dashboard development, and system evaluation, ultimately providing stakeholders with insights into learning progress and resource usage.
summaries.Læringsteknologi: This master's project explores learning technology, encompassing software and technological products that support learning and teaching. The project offers flexibility for student-selected tasks, either individually or in collaboration with faculty. Projects can be related to the Excited center for excellent education. Expected outcomes include advancements in learning technology and potential contributions to the Excited center.
summaries.LLM-enhanced computerized adaptive testi: This project proposes developing an LLM-enhanced Computerized Adaptive Testing (CAT) system for programming education. The system will use multiple-choice questions from a repository like Web-CAT, adapting question difficulty based on student performance. An LLM will provide explanations for answers. The project aims to evaluate the effectiveness of CAT in CS1 and CS2 courses within higher education.
summaries.Learning software organisations: This project investigates organizational learning and knowledge management within software companies, focusing on how these processes occur at different organizational levels, particularly at the team level. It begins with a literature review on organizational learning and knowledge management in software engineering. The project may extend into an empirical study within a Norwegian software engineering environment, potentially using a case study suggested by the student or found through the supervisor's network. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how software organizations facilitate learning and knowledge sharing.
summaries.Hybrid human‐AI learning technologies: This project explores the design of hybrid human-AI learning technologies, focusing on the augmentation perspective in education. It involves designing learning services (interfaces/artifacts) using co-design or participatory design methods. The project will utilize the six levels of automation model to define roles for AI users (learners, teachers) and articulate the transition of control between them and the technology. Expected outcomes include showcasing the challenges and opportunities of hybrid human-AI learning and defining the roles of AI in education.
summaries.Innovative education at the intersection: This project explores the integration of XR (VR/AR) and generative AI (ChatGPT) to innovate education at NTNU. It investigates developing virtual classrooms with ChatGPT-powered virtual teaching assistants for 24/7 student support and personalized feedback. The project also examines using generative AI to rapidly create 3D educational content for XR environments, addressing content creation barriers for educators. The research will utilize the IMTEL VR lab's extensive equipment.
summaries.Hybrid co-design toolkits: This project explores adapting traditional co-design methods and toolkits for hybrid environments, addressing the shift towards digital interaction in design workshops. The research involves a literature review, the creation of a framework for comparing co-design strategies, and the development of hybrid toolkit prototypes as case studies. The expected outcome is a better understanding of hybrid co-design and practical toolkits to facilitate inclusive participation in IT product development.
summaries.Investigating and comparing alternatives: This project investigates alternatives to the Eclipse Modeling Framework (EMF) for Model-Driven Engineering, considering the shift towards languages like Python and web-based applications. It involves analyzing tools like Langium and PyEcore, comparing their features and functionalities against EMF in standardized scenarios. The goal is to identify suitable alternatives for modern development scenarios, considering metamodeling and language infrastructure creation. Expected outcomes include a comparative analysis of different tools and their applicability in diverse contexts.
summaries.Investigating LLMs for the verification: This project investigates the use of Large Language Models (LLMs) for verifying if source code adheres to coding quality rules, focusing on security and performance. The research involves applying open-source LLMs to identify code violations, potentially by directly identifying violations or configuring static analysis tools. Experimentation includes tuning and pre-processing data to improve model performance. The goal is to automate the implementation of checkers for new coding rules specified in natural language. Technologies used include LLMs, Python, Java/C++, and potentially static analysis tools like SonarQube.
summaries.Learning analytics and AI learning syste: This project investigates the use of learning analytics (LA) and AI learning systems in Norway. It involves analyzing existing data from national organizations like Sikt and NOKUT, and potentially collecting primary data through questionnaires or interviews. The goal is to identify the types of LA and AI systems used, their practical applications, and associated challenges and opportunities. The project requires a background in data analysis and research methods, but no programming skills. Expected outcomes include a comprehensive understanding of LA and AI learning system adoption and impact within the Norwegian educational context.
summaries.Investigating LLMs for model-to-model tr: This project investigates the application of Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate model transformation tasks in software engineering. The research involves using open-source LLMs to generate code in specialized languages (e.g., ATL, Epsilon) for transforming semi-formal models (e.g., UML diagrams). The methodology includes a literature review, experimentation with publicly available models and transformations (e.g., ATL Transformation Zoo), and tuning data to improve LLM performance. The expected outcome is an evaluation of LLMs' ability to write correct model transformations from examples, contributing to the long-term goal of building an LLM-based model transformation engine.
summaries.Implementation and Evaluation of Scalar: This project focuses on implementing and evaluating a scalar evolution analysis within the JLM compiler, which utilizes the Regionalized Value State Dependence Graph (RVSDG) intermediate representation. The goal is to analyze how scalar variables change within loops to enable loop optimizations and simplifications. The project involves understanding scalar evolution theory, the RVSDG, and the JLM compiler's codebase. The implementation will be done in C++ using the LLVM infrastructure, and the evaluation will assess the impact of the analysis on loop transformations.
summaries.Qualitative study of Microsoft Copilot u: This project investigates how computing students at NTNU use Microsoft Copilot and its impact on their learning. The research employs a qualitative case study approach, utilizing observations, interviews, and archival data collection. The goal is to understand the practices of students using Copilot through qualitative data analysis. Expected outcomes include a rich understanding of Copilot usage patterns and their effects on student learning in a computing context.
summaries.Organizational decision-making in the ag: This project investigates the impact of AI adoption on organizational decision-making processes. It will empirically examine the effects and transition dynamics as organizations integrate AI for tasks like credit checks, forecasting, and automation. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how AI reshapes decision-making structures within organizations.
summaries.Reinforcement learning for multi-agent s: This project explores multi-agent reinforcement learning for autonomous driving in simulated urban environments. The research focuses on developing a reinforcement learning scheme to control multiple simulated vehicles. The project can utilize the CARLA simulator or Agilex.ai LIMO robots. Expected outcomes include a functional multi-agent autonomous driving system and insights into the application of reinforcement learning in this domain.
summaries.Multiplayer game development using Web3: This project focuses on developing a multiplayer Blackjack game using Web3 technologies, combining traditional web development with blockchain. Key technologies include a frontend UI framework, Web3 JavaScript libraries, a Spring Boot backend, and Solidity smart contracts on an EVM-compatible blockchain. The game will feature blockchain wallet-linked accounts, token transfers, and automated prize distribution. Research areas include user identity/security, scalability, account abstraction, Play2Earn aspects, cross-chain interoperability, user onboarding, and architectural best practices. The expected outcome is a functional multiplayer game demonstrating the integration of Web3 technologies and exploration of related research challenges.
summaries.Processing and analysing ice data: This project focuses on processing and analyzing ice data, specifically satellite data, for shipping in the Arctic and Baltic Sea regions. It aims to identify needs for satellite data, assess existing services and products, and analyze how the data is currently used. The research is part of a larger ESA/EC-financed project exploring EO data applications in maritime, oil & gas, and raw material extraction. Expected outcomes include insights into satellite data utilization and potential improvements for Arctic and Baltic Sea shipping.
summaries.Ready for digital transformation - a co-: This project proposes developing a card-based co-design toolkit to aid workers in navigating digital transformation within their workplaces. The toolkit will foster creativity and system-thinking while considering existing infrastructure constraints. Inspired by Tiles, the tool aims to help users understand the possibilities of new technologies and promote meaningful participation in digital transformation initiatives. The expected outcome is a practical tool that enhances workers' competence and contributes to successful technology adoption.
summaries.Online Learning Platform – Enhancing Per: This project enhances the Progresso online learning platform by integrating a Self-Regulated Learning (SRL) module. The research involves a literature review of SRL in e-learning, followed by the design, implementation, and iterative testing of the SRL module using React/Next.js, Node.js, Prisma ORM, and Firebase. A user study will assess the module's impact on learning efficiency, engagement, and retention. The expected outcome is a refined SRL-enhanced platform and a documented evaluation of its effectiveness.
summaries.On the relation between software enginee: This empirical software engineering project investigates the relationship between software engineering practices and AI adoption in Norway. It will analyze data from TDT4290 projects, conduct literature reviews, interview customers and students, and analyze reports and software. The expected outcome is a comprehensive understanding of current trends and practices in developing AI-intensive systems within the Norwegian context.
summaries.Reflective and collaborative game for le: This project focuses on designing a game to enhance digital competence related to AI understanding and usage across various contexts like schools and workplaces. The project involves defining specific learning objectives, target groups, game genres, and technologies in collaboration with the supervisor. The expected outcome includes game design, prototyping, and evaluation to foster AI literacy.
summaries.Open data and data platforms – how to su: This project investigates the social, technical, practical, and organizational conditions necessary for successful open data initiatives, focusing on the Open Data Subsurface Universe (OSDU) platform. The research will explore challenges like motivation, technical infrastructure feasibility, and reward models within the context of partner companies such as Equinor and AkerBP. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how to effectively implement and utilize open data platforms for increased collaboration and productivity across industries, particularly in energy and resource management.
summaries.Ready for digital transformation - a gam: This project proposes designing a game to enhance workers' understanding of new technologies and their impact in the context of digital transformation. The game will focus on fostering systemic and critical thinking skills. The project involves game design, prototyping, and evaluation, with the specific area of interest, game genre, and technology to be defined in collaboration with the supervisor. The expected outcome is a game that effectively prepares workers for digital transformation by improving their competence and understanding of new technologies.
summaries.Reinforcement learning for multi-agent s: This project explores multi-agent reinforcement learning for autonomous driving in a simulated urban environment. The research focuses on developing a reinforcement learning scheme to enable self-learning agents (simulated cars) to navigate and interact effectively. The expected outcome is a functional multi-agent system capable of autonomous navigation, demonstrating the application of reinforcement learning in complex traffic scenarios.
summaries.Omniverse, Content generation, Simulatio: This project aims to create a near real-time photorealistic digital twin of the Gløs campus using Omniverse and USD, leveraging existing geospatial data and real-time updates. The project will explore automated 3D content creation from 2D images and integrate the environment into simulators like DRIVE Sim and Isaac Sim for autonomous driving agent training using imitation and reinforcement learning. The trained AI models will be fine-tuned with real-world data and applied to an autonomous vehicle platform for further research.
summaries.NBA Excitement Rater - Development of an: This project aims to develop an "Excitement Score" for NBA games, enabling fans to choose replays based on predicted entertainment value. The project involves researching key metrics, collaborating with Sportradar to design an algorithm, building an accessible Excitement Score pipeline, and testing the feature with NBA fans. The expected outcome is a functional tool that enhances the NBA viewing experience by providing data-driven game recommendations.
summaries.Open Foundation Models / LLM (type ChatG: This project explores fine-tuning open-source Foundation Models/LLMs for health applications within a Digital Twin. It investigates model personalization using health data from wearables, integration for natural language interaction with a digital twin, and explainability methods. Key research areas include identifying suitable open-source models, addressing privacy, security, and ethical challenges, and leveraging resources like Lamina.ai and Med-PaLM 2. The expected outcome is a personalized FM/LLM integrated into a digital twin, capable of knowledgeable and empathetic health-related conversations.
summaries.Óne citizen - óne digital health twin (a: This project explores developing a digital health twin ecosystem, leveraging wearable data (smartwatches, health monitors) within the MIA Health platform. The research focuses on expanding activity data integration, incorporating sleep data, and converting MIA from a data lake to a predictive digital twin using generic models and potentially fine-tuned LLMs. It also considers novel clinical study methodologies and addresses privacy, security, and ethical considerations within the health data context. Expected outcomes include enhanced UX/frontend, backend development, system architecture for model handling, and innovative approaches to data-driven health services.
summaries.Next-Gen Report Service Project Manageme: This project modernizes a reporting service for a JavaScript project management application by replacing the .NET/Crystal Reports system with an API-based solution using JSON. Key features include multi-format report generation (.docx, .pdf), user-friendly report blueprint creation with advanced graphics and 3D visualizations, large-scale data handling, and automated multi-recipient delivery. The expected outcomes are a streamlined reporting process, enhanced data presentation and analysis, and a scalable, future-proof solution aligned with modern standards.
summaries.Open data - from vision to reality?: This project investigates the gap between the vision of open data and its practical implementation, focusing on the Open Data Subsurface Universe (OSDU) platform. It will analyze the social, practical, and institutional conditions necessary for successful open data adoption within the energy sector (fossil, renewable, and CCS). The research will involve collaboration with industry partners like Equinor and AkerBP to assess the challenges and opportunities of using OSDU for data sharing, communication, and analytics related to geo-located assets. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how to bridge the gap between open data availability and its effective use.
summaries.Predictive Maintenance in Fish Farming: This project aims to develop predictive maintenance methods for fish farming operations, focusing on automating the prediction of maintenance needs to optimize cleaning cycles and reduce downtime. The research will identify and rank maintenance operations based on economic impact and then develop predictive models to detect maintenance needs before problems occur.
