The project will leverage data and technology in collaboration with Piscada, utilizing their industrial cloud-based software platform. The expected outcome is a reliable system for predicting maintenance needs, improving efficiency and sustainability in fish farming.
summaries.Predictive Maintenance in Building Autom: This project explores predictive maintenance in building automation, specifically HVAC systems, to optimize maintenance schedules and reduce unnecessary replacements. The research will identify and rank maintenance operations suitable for automated prediction based on economic impact. The core objective is to develop predictive methods for these operations, enabling early detection of maintenance needs. This project will be in collaboration with Piscada, and will leverage their industrial cloud platform. Expected outcomes include improved maintenance efficiency, reduced costs, and increased sustainability.
summaries.Teamwork in software development: This project proposes a literature review of teamwork research within software development, particularly focusing on agile and distributed teams. It aims to synthesize existing knowledge on team performance models and empirical studies to identify factors influencing team effectiveness. The project can be extended into a master's thesis involving an empirical study to further investigate these factors.
summaries.Smart Desks: This project explores the creation of "smart" or "context-aware" desks to facilitate shared office space. The research involves studying existing literature, designing and implementing IoT-based prototypes with accompanying software, and conducting user tests to evaluate the solution. The expected outcome is a functional prototype and insights into optimizing desk sharing through technology.
summaries.The Strategic Value of Big Data Analytic: This project investigates the strategic value of big data analytics in Norwegian companies. Through a quantitative study, the research will examine how these companies apply big data analytics to generate business value. The project involves collaboration with the Big Data Observatory, focusing on developing research methods and analyzing quantitative data to understand the impact of big data analytics on business outcomes.
summaries.Shared Situational Awareness through Rol: This project explores enhancing shared situational awareness in industrial operations by integrating Active Knowledge Models (AKM) and role-based workspaces with the OSDU data platform. The research involves extracting data and information objects from OSDU, creating and enhancing data elements using IRTV constructs within the AKM modeller. A key task is developing new meta-model capabilities supporting formal modeling standards like Archimate for OSDU integration. Expected outcomes include functional use cases and a meta-model, with potential for knowledge transfer across industries. This work is in collaboration with Equinor.
summaries.Supporting learning with cutting-edge XR: This project explores the potential of advanced XR technology, including Apple Vision Pro, VR treadmills, and haptic suits/gloves, to enhance learning experiences at the university and professional levels. The research will focus on how these technologies can support advanced 3D visualization, spatial computing games, and simulations requiring haptic feedback. The project will leverage the IMTEL VR lab's resources to develop and evaluate educational applications, with a specific topic to be defined in collaboration with the student. Expected outcomes include insights into the effective use of cutting-edge XR for education.
summaries.Smart Urban Data Collection for Health a: This project investigates urban health and well-being using mobile phone and smartwatch data collection. It combines quantitative data with individual perceptions gathered in outdoor and public spaces. The research involves literature review, study design, data collection and analysis, and identifying design implications. The expected outcome is a comprehensive understanding of individual well-being in urban environments, contributing to the NTNU SWELL sustainability project.
summaries.Shipyard simulator for planning ship-bre: This project aims to develop a shipyard simulator for planning ship-breaking activities, addressing the inefficiencies and safety concerns of current 2D planning methods. The simulator will visualize 3D ship models, allowing users to define cutting plans and preview outcomes. Key activities include understanding current shipyard practices, developing the simulator with user input capabilities, and gathering feedback on its effectiveness. This project is part of the SHEREC project, focusing on improving safety through digitalization and robotics in ship-breaking. Expected outcomes include a functional simulator and insights into its impact on planning efficiency and safety.
summaries.Reliability evaluation of approximate co: This project evaluates the reliability of compiler-level approximate computing techniques using fault injection. The research involves extending existing approximate computing benchmarks with fault tolerance capabilities by injecting faults into the code. The goal is to compare the fault tolerance of different approximate computing algorithms. The project requires C/C++ programming, Git, and CMake experience. Expected outcomes include a literature review of fault injection techniques and an extended benchmark for evaluating approximate computing algorithms under fault conditions.
summaries.Safety evaluation of trajectory planners: This project evaluates the safety of trajectory planning algorithms in autonomous vehicles, building upon existing object detection research. It involves a literature review of safety metrics for trajectory planners, applying these metrics to existing algorithms using datasets like nuScenes or simulators like CARLA, and experimenting with algorithm variations. The goal is to understand the behavior of these algorithms and contribute to defining a benchmark for assessing autonomous vehicle safety. The project requires experience with machine learning for object detection and familiarity with git.
summaries.Smidig transformasjon: This project explores the challenges of "agile transformation" in organizations, moving beyond software development teams. It begins with a literature review of agile transformation within system development, information systems, and change management. A potential extension involves an empirical study of organizations undergoing agile transformations, potentially leveraging data from the Agile 2.0 research project. The research aims to understand and address resistance to organizational changes and difficulties in adapting agile processes across diverse organizational functions.
summaries.System for vurdering av prosjekt og kode: This project focuses on developing a submission and feedback system for project and programming courses. It will explore functionalities such as code review, peer assessment of projects, automated testing, and the integration of generative AI. The system aims to improve learning through diverse feedback mechanisms, including instructor feedback, peer reviews, and automated analysis. Expected outcomes include a functional system capable of providing comprehensive feedback and potentially summarizing/quality-assuring peer assessments.
summaries.The potential of Artificial Intelligence: This project investigates the adoption of Artificial Intelligence (AI) in public administration, in collaboration with SINTEF Digital. It involves data collection and analysis to determine the current status, potential applications, and realized value of AI implementations within public organizations. The research will explore AI's use in areas like fraud detection, chatbots, and infrastructure monitoring, aiming to understand its impact and potential benefits in the public sector. The expected outcome is a report detailing the findings on AI adoption and its value in public administration.
summaries.Species prediction models applied to vul: This project explores applying species prediction models to software vulnerability detection. It aims to adapt models inspired by species accumulation curves to analyze the cumulative number of software vulnerabilities discovered over time, using historical data and software complexity metrics. The expected outcome is a model that predicts the rate of new vulnerability discoveries and estimates the total number of vulnerabilities in a software system, aiding in bug hunting strategies.
summaries.Responsible AI in organizations: This project explores the organizational implications of responsible AI adoption. It investigates the processes and structures organizations implement to achieve responsible AI indicators. The research aims to identify organizational gains, impacts on customer/citizen perception, and potential restrictions on technology use resulting from responsible AI adoption. The expected outcome is a comprehensive understanding of responsible AI's influence on organizational dynamics and stakeholder perceptions.
summaries.Tag inference: This project aims to develop a model for automated equipment tag inference using time series data from Building Automation Systems. The student will preprocess time series data, select a suitable classification model, and evaluate class optimization through clustering. Utilizing years of high-frequency data from numerous buildings, the model will classify equipment based on its data emissions over a two-week period. The expected outcome is a functional model that can accurately infer equipment tags, contributing to Piscada's industrial cloud-based software platform for PropTech and Industrial IoT.
summaries.Sustainable migration of cloud infrastru: This project investigates sustainable cloud migration strategies to mitigate vendor lock-in, a significant challenge in cloud computing. It will review existing methods and explore practical solutions for reducing vendor dependency and enabling multi-cloud support. The expected outcome is a set of strategies and recommendations for organizations to achieve more flexible, cost-effective, and sustainable cloud infrastructure.
summaries.Sustainability by design: This project explores integrating sustainability into software development by addressing how to express, elicit, and balance sustainability requirements within agile methods. It includes a literature review and evaluation of techniques for handling sustainability requirements. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how to achieve sustainability by design in IT solutions, with consideration of both short-term and long-term adherence to sustainability goals. The project is affiliated with NTNU Center for Sustainable ICT (CESICT) and the goforIT network.
summaries.Samarbeide og kommunikasjon i helsesekto: This project investigates challenges in healthcare collaboration due to fragmented information systems hindering seamless patient care across different healthcare providers. It aims to analyze the implementation of a digital service within the healthcare sector, employing empirical methods like observation, interviews, and system usage logging to gather requirements. The project will operationalize these requirements into recommended functionalities, potentially including a prototype, to improve distributed workflow support and enhance healthcare collaboration.
summaries.System for tidlig deteksjon av dysleksi: This project focuses on developing and evaluating a system for early dyslexia detection based on visual processing dysfunction, specifically related to magnocellular function. The system aims to assess visual information processing in children to identify potential indicators of dyslexia. The project involves collaboration with the psychology department and builds upon existing research, with the goal of practical application in child testing.
summaries.Semi-supervised learning for enhancing r: This project focuses on improving bird species recognition, particularly for rare species, using semi-supervised learning techniques. The research will leverage the Sound of Norway dataset (7TB of audio) and build upon the existing BirdNET classifier. The project will explore fine-tuning, few-shot learning, and other methods to enhance the model's accuracy and recall for underrepresented species. The expected outcome is a more robust bird classifier that contributes to better biodiversity assessments by accurately identifying rare bird species.
summaries.Visual Simultaneous Localization and Map: This project focuses on developing a Visual Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (VSLAM) system tailored for underwater snake robots, addressing challenges like limited visibility and poor illumination. The research will involve experimenting with novel approaches in geometric models, statistical estimation, or machine learning to improve keypoint tracking, pose graph optimization, or depth estimation. The project may also integrate IMU measurements. The expected outcome is a robust VSLAM system validated using real underwater video footage and a realistic simulation environment.
summaries.Transforming IT operations: organisation: This project investigates the challenges organizations face when transitioning to DevOps. It explores how traditional IT operations functions can be reorganized within a DevOps model. The research aims to understand how organizations have managed this transition, focusing on the organizational perspectives of adopting DevOps practices. The expected outcome is a better understanding of successful strategies for implementing DevOps in organizations.
summaries.What is the Business Value of Artificial: This master's project explores the business value of AI by examining the readiness of private and public organizations to adopt AI technologies and the value derived from these investments. The research will involve data collection and analysis in collaboration with the Big Data Observatory. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how organizations plan to use AI and the necessary steps for successful AI adoption.
summaries.Toolkit for Technologically Rich Educati: This project aims to develop a digital toolkit to support K-12 students in technology-rich Design Thinking activities (Empathize, Ideate, Define, Prototype, Test). The toolkit will guide students through collaborative problem-solving and gather data on their performance. The project involves a literature review, iterative toolkit design (platform or website), data gathering/analysis, and user testing. Expected outcomes include a functional toolkit, insights into student learning processes, and an evaluation of the toolkit's efficacy. Required skills include software/interface design, JavaScript programming, and interest in user-centered research.
summaries.Verification of coding conventions for J: This project aims to use GitHub CodeQL to verify coding rules for Java, specifically focusing on the SEI Cert Oracle Coding Standard. The research involves writing CodeQL queries to detect violations of these rules in reference projects. The results will be compared with existing static analysis tools. The goal is to assess CodeQL's effectiveness in enforcing code quality and to improve techniques for verifying code quality rules in source code.
summaries.Use of honeypots for understanding attac: This project investigates honeypots simulating n-day vulnerable software to understand attacker methodologies and improve network security. A systematic literature review will identify research gaps, focusing on differentiating automated vs. manual attacks, honeypot realism and security, deployment strategies, threat intelligence, and anti-honeypot techniques. The expected outcome is a deeper understanding of honeypot effectiveness in detecting and mitigating cyber threats, informing better security operations.
summaries.XR4Colab - Remote Learning and Collabora: This project explores AR-supported collaborative learning using Hololens 2, focusing on design principles and tools for remote education and collaboration. The research will involve working with Hololens 2 units and potentially collaborating with companies like Equinor, St. Olavs hospital, or NTNU courses. The expected outcome is a better understanding of how AR can enhance remote learning experiences.
summaries.Understanding an organisation's adaptive: This project investigates how organizations adapt to IT incidents, addressing concerns about the sufficiency of current cybersecurity practices amidst increasing cyberattacks and digital transformation. It adopts a resilience engineering perspective, drawing from safety research, to understand the socio-technical aspects of IT operations and incident response. The research aims to analyze collaborative practices crucial for maintaining software system performance, contributing to a deeper understanding of incident management in complex IT environments.
summaries.XR4Edu - XR in Education: This project explores the use of XR (VR/AR) in education, aiming to create immersive and interactive learning experiences. Potential applications include virtual university environments, tools for teaching computer graphics, deep learning, echocardiography, fetal ultrasound, and understanding the relationship between heart function and cerebral blood flow in neonates. The project also considers collaborative learning in AR/VR and merging existing tools into joint applications. Expected outcomes include innovative XR tools and methodologies for enhanced education in various fields.
summaries.Understanding the execution behavior of: This project aims to develop a tool to analyze the execution behavior of high-level productivity languages (Python, NodeJS, Javascript) on modern hardware. The research will focus on differentiating application code and data within processor caches to understand how these languages interact with front-end and back-end processor components. The expected outcome is a tool that enables precise tracking of application behavior and informs the design of more efficient and energy-conscious hardware architectures for these languages.
summaries.What are the skills of the future: A loo: This project investigates the evolving skills required of computer science graduates due to the rise of AI and big data analytics. In collaboration with the Big Data Observatory, the research will employ focus groups and surveys to gather data from industry representatives. The expected outcome is a detailed analysis of essential skills and recommendations for educational institutions to adapt their curricula to meet industry demands.
summaries.Unlocking Insights from Video Content –: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) to analyze spoken content from YouTube videos. It involves building a system to automatically retrieve and process transcripts from videos and playlists using the YouTube API. The system will employ LLMs for topic extraction, summarization, and trend visualization, presented through a user-friendly interface. A user study will evaluate the system's effectiveness. The expected outcome is a tool that provides meaningful insights from large amounts of video content.
summaries.Visual Intelligence and accurate geo-ref: This project aims to develop a mobile application leveraging visual intelligence and precise geo-referencing for road object assessment. Utilizing a mobile device's camera and accurate positioning equipment (e.g., u-blox with CPos), the app will employ AI models to evaluate and geo-reference the condition of visible road objects. Expected outcomes include a functional application for road condition assessment and potential applications in HD-map creation, real-time image matching for localization, and data collection for neural rendering. The project is a collaboration between national road authorities, SINTEF, and municipalities.
summaries.Zero Emission Farm – digital game design: This project focuses on designing and developing a digital game to promote awareness and knowledge about zero-emission farms and reducing greenhouse gas emissions in agriculture. The project will involve reviewing existing solutions, iteratively designing and developing the game, and validating its effectiveness. The work will be conducted in collaboration with Mære Agricultural School and will leverage the Climate Calculator. The expected outcome is a functional game that effectively educates users about sustainable farming practices.
summaries.Visualisering av kriterier for nullutsli: This project explores the visualization of criteria for zero-emission zones, focusing on data collection and dashboard development. It aims to create dashboards for various areas, supported by a data architecture that provides access to necessary data. The research will employ a design science research methodology, with the goal of producing a scientific publication. The expected outcome is a practical solution for monitoring and visualizing zero-emission zone criteria, contributing to the development of sustainable urban areas.
summaries.XR4CE - Citizen Engagement with XR: This project explores using Extended Reality (XR) technologies to enhance citizen engagement in e-governance. It aims to develop tools for efficient knowledge transfer, communication, and feedback collection from citizens regarding policies and strategies. The research will address challenges related to subjective constraints and aim to objectify citizen input within XR environments. The expected outcome is a conceptualization and practical XR application designed to improve citizen engagement.
summaries.XR4Med - Augmented reality tools for int: This project explores using augmented reality (AR) to enhance intra-operative visualization during cardiac ultrasound exams and bronchoscopies. It aims to integrate data from multiple image sources into a unified AR display within the operator's field of view. By leveraging an existing open-source platform, the project seeks to improve operator ergonomics and procedural success rates. The research focuses on intelligent data presentation and visualization in AR, with potential applications in bronchoscopy and echocardiography.
summaries.Workplace training in Virtual Reality in: This project explores using Virtual Reality (VR) and gamification to improve workplace training and career guidance for young job seekers. In collaboration with the VR4VET Erasmus+ project and NAV, the research will focus on simulating workplaces (e.g., aquaculture, shipyards) to allow users to safely explore tasks and acquire skills. The project will utilize the IMTEL VR lab's extensive equipment (Apple Vision Pro, Valve Index, etc.). Expected outcomes include enhanced motivation, faster skill acquisition, and a novel approach to vocational training.
summaries.Unsupervised learning for automatically: This project explores unsupervised learning techniques for automating eye movement annotation in eye-tracking data, addressing the challenges of data inaccuracies. It involves assessing existing datasets, applying unsupervised learning algorithms, and using data augmentation to improve annotation accuracy. The automatically generated annotations will be compared to existing annotations. The project also aims to investigate the applicability of these methods to eye tracking data from VR headsets, accounting for the relative movement between the eye and the tracking cameras.
summaries.Using LLMs and conversational agents to: This project explores using LLMs and conversational agents within a mobile application to enhance children's science learning. It involves literature review, app development integrating (Multimodal) LLMs (e.g., CodeLLama) and conversational mechanics, and user studies in schools or science museums. The goal is to empirically test the system's impact on children's engagement and understanding of scientific concepts. The project requires skills in UX design, (M)LLM integration, and front-end programming (JavaScript, CSS).
summaries.AI for eyesight: This project explores the application of AI, specifically computer vision, to diagnose eyesight issues and improve spectacle design. Conducted in collaboration with an international startup, the research aims to develop innovative solutions for addressing eyesight problems, potentially impacting the third world. The project focuses on industrial applications within the field of eyesight diagnostics.
summaries.Exploration of GraphRAG-extracted Knowle: This project explores knowledge graphs extracted by GraphRAG, a structured RAG approach, to evaluate their quality and utility beyond question answering. The research aims to enhance understanding of GraphRAG's reasoning capabilities by developing a tool for efficient knowledge graph exploration, potentially using a graph database. The expected outcome is a deeper insight into the value of GraphRAG-extracted knowledge graphs for downstream tasks.
summaries.Bio-inspired techniques applied to remot: This project explores bio-inspired techniques for hyperspectral remote sensing data analysis. Focusing on challenges posed by high dimensionality and redundancy, the research aims to improve classification and monitoring of environmental changes. The project builds upon previous work using evolutionary algorithms for spectral band selection. Current work involves applying Particle Swarm Optimization and superpixel analysis. The project welcomes students to explore alternative bio-inspired methods or focus on other aspects of hyperspectral image processing. Expected outcomes include improved data processing techniques and enhanced environmental monitoring capabilities.
summaries.Evaluation of Streaming Graph Processing: This project evaluates existing streaming graph processing frameworks to address the gap in research compared to static graph processing. The goal is to design a prototype processing pipeline for efficient analytics on real-world streaming graphs. The project requires a basic understanding of graph theory, algorithms, and data analytics technologies. The expected outcome is a functional prototype and an evaluation of current streaming graph processing frameworks.
summaries.Exciting topics in HPC & Parallel Comput: This project explores high-performance and parallel computing topics, including parallel algorithms, GPU features (specifically NVIDIA B100 testing), quantum computing simulations, and cloud technologies. It also considers developing edutainment for teaching parallel programming. The expected outcome is a feasible project, potentially a Master's thesis, focusing on investigating new HPC systems and educational tools.
summaries.Event Mining and Linking: This project focuses on mining and linking events from large news archives to create coherent storylines for users. It will employ data mining, information retrieval, and natural language processing techniques to extract events and contextualize them with related prior information. The expected outcome is a system capable of weaving events together, enhancing end-user comprehension of complex news topics.
summaries.Evolving personalised training programs: This project aims to develop personalized training programs using a Genetic Algorithm to mitigate Metabolic Syndrome. The algorithm will generate dynamic exercise routines that evolve with the patient's health status, promoting long-term well-being. The expected outcome is a system that helps individuals adhere to effective exercise regimens, reducing the risk of cardiovascular diseases and type 2 diabetes associated with Metabolic Syndrome.
summaries.Further development of a novel immune-in: This project aims to further develop the MAIM hybrid classification algorithm, which combines features of the Immune System with an Island Model Genetic Algorithm (IGA). Building upon promising preliminary results from previous work, the project will explore avenues to extend and refine the algorithm. The expected outcome is an improved classification algorithm with enhanced anomaly recognition capabilities.
summaries.Customized Query Execution Plans in Grap: This project aims to develop a system for injecting custom query execution plans and cardinalities into property graph databases like Kùzu or Neo4j. Building upon the concept of PgCuckoo for relational databases, the research will design and implement a solution that allows external optimizers to influence query planning within graph databases. The expected outcome is a tool that facilitates experimentation and research on query optimization strategies in graph database systems.
summaries.GPU adaptations of 3D shape matching alg: This project explores GPU adaptations of 3D shape matching algorithms to improve performance. The research focuses on parallelizing existing CPU-based algorithms for implementation on GPUs, addressing challenges related to memory bandwidth and non-direct GPU mappings. The expected outcome is faster execution times, enabling practical applications of 3D shape matching in areas like robotics.
summaries.An immune system approach to fake News C: This project explores an immune system-inspired approach to fake news classification, leveraging antibody and antigen concepts. The goal is to extend and refine existing methods in this area. Specific research directions will be determined by the student. Expected outcomes include improved fake news detection and a deeper understanding of applying immunological principles to natural language processing.
summaries.[NorwAI] Neural Machine Translation in W: This project explores Neural Machine Translation (NMT) between Bokmål and Nynorsk using a Generative Pre-trained Transformer (GPT) model. It addresses the challenge of limited parallel data by investigating methods to leverage pre-trained language models for translation. The project involves a literature review, designing an efficient GPT-based NMT approach, and evaluating its applicability. The research utilizes the Norwegian Colossal Corpus and a NorwAI-provided GPT model. Expected outcomes include an efficient NMT model and solutions to challenges like named entity recognition, long text translation, and reducing training overhead.
summaries.[NorwAI] Sentiment Analysis Based on Bra: This project aims to develop an objective sentiment analysis method using fMRI brain signals to map neural activity to perceived sentiment of individual words. The research involves literature review, data collection of text and MRI scans, system design to correlate fMRI signals with sentiment categories, and system evaluation by estimating sentiment load of words in sentences. Expected outcomes include a system capable of accurately estimating continuous sentiment from text and MRI data, applicable to various fields like healthcare and social media.
summaries.Human Pose Estimation for VR-exergaming: This project explores human pose estimation (HPE) for VR-exergaming in rehabilitation. It involves developing a VR-exergame prototype in Unity and integrating a multi-ocular HPE model for real-time feedback and game control. The research will test and compare HPE frameworks, generate real-time performance feedback, and optionally implement a virtual therapist. User testing will evaluate the system's usability, focusing on easy setup and calibration for the target user group. The expected outcome is a VR-exergame prototype utilizing HPE for improved rehabilitation feedback and motivation.
summaries.Analysing the Effectiveness of Last Leve: This project investigates the effectiveness of Last Level Caches (LLC) for cloud applications, which often have large data working sets. The research will use hardware simulation to analyze the performance of cloud workloads under different cache configurations and eviction policies. The goal is to identify bottlenecks and explore potential solutions to reduce energy consumption, area usage, and wasted cycles in future processor designs. The project requires expertise in system architecture and hardware/software interaction.
summaries.Developing an autofocus for 3D shape mat: This project aims to develop an "autofocus" algorithm for 3D shape matching, automating the selection of the scale parameter crucial for comparing 3D surfaces. The research will focus on ensuring consistent scale estimation between corresponding points on similar surfaces, even with alterations. The expected outcome is an algorithm that dynamically adjusts the scale parameter, improving the accuracy and robustness of 3D shape matching algorithms used in applications like robotic navigation.
summaries.Åpne data og dataplattformer – fangstreg: This project explores the implementation of open data and data platforms within the Norwegian fisheries sector, focusing on catch registration. It will investigate the social, technical, and organizational challenges hindering the adoption of open data initiatives. The research will involve collaboration with SINTEF Nord, Norges Fiskerihøgskole (UiT), the Norwegian Directorate of Fisheries, and the fishing industry. Expected outcomes include identifying solutions for overcoming barriers to open data adoption and promoting sustainable fishing practices through technologies like AI and image recognition.
summaries.An Immune System Approach to Music recom: This project explores applying immune system algorithms, specifically AIRS or similar approaches, to music recommendation systems. Building upon existing work using AIRS for content-based filtering in Automatic Playlist Continuation (APC), the project aims to enhance recommendation accuracy. The research may extend the approach to incorporate collaborative filtering techniques in addition to content-based methods. The expected outcome is a music recommendation system that leverages immunological principles to provide more personalized and relevant music suggestions to users.
summaries.Extending hybrid vector search (multiple: This project explores extensions to hybrid vector search, combining approximate nearest neighbor search with additional constraints like filtering, spatial features, or multi-modal data. The research focuses on developing and evaluating new algorithms and indexes for tasks such as combining vector search with database operations, streaming hybrid vector search, and GPU-enhanced extensions. The project involves studying existing work, implementing algorithms in C++, and evaluating performance on large datasets using pre-trained embeddings. Expected outcomes include novel algorithms and indexes for improved hybrid vector search performance.
summaries.Database opportunities at Huawei Researc: This project explores opportunities within Huawei's database research lab in Trondheim, focusing on Hybrid Transactional/Analytical Processing (HTAP) in cloud-native database systems. Research areas include utilizing metadata and storage indexes for faster query processing, running machine learning within cloud databases, managing semi-structured data in OLAP systems, gathering statistics for external data, caching intermediate results in query engines, streaming data transformation techniques, and information lifecycle management across different storage tiers. The expected outcome is improved efficiency and performance of HTAP systems through optimized data management and query processing strategies.
summaries.Text Driven Analytics and Visualization: This project focuses on developing a system for text-driven analytics and visualization, leveraging scalable information extraction techniques on web-based text documents. The system will process annotations like entities, time, and numbers to generate insightful visualizations, enabling users to perform text-driven analysis. The research areas include databases, information retrieval, and data mining.
summaries.NoSQL/NewSQL (scalable) databases: This project explores NoSQL/NewSQL databases, focusing on scalability and performance. Potential research areas include transaction models in NewSQL, multi-dimensional indexing in NoSQL, autotuning, automatic upgrades, autoscaling, and indexing/storage strategies. The project aims to optimize database performance and management, potentially tailored to a specific database based on the student's preference. Expected outcomes include improved database efficiency and automation of key operational tasks.
summaries.Scaling algorithms for databases: This project investigates hashing algorithms for scalable, distributed databases, building upon previous theoretical work. The research will focus on practical implementation and evaluation of various hashing algorithms to determine their suitability for database scaling. The expected outcome is a comparative analysis of hashing algorithms, identifying the most effective options for enhancing the scalability of distributed databases.
summaries.Recognizing meta-data on car tires: This project aims to automate car tire meta-data extraction using computer vision. Leveraging a large image dataset of tires, the project will develop models to predict tire size, manufacturer, estimate profile depth, and detect damages. The expected outcome is an automated system that reduces manual effort in tire maintenance, supported by Trønderdekk AS.
summaries.[2023/2024 Collaboration with Refinitiv: This project explores deep learning models for detecting wind turbine curtailment to improve wind power output forecasts. It aims to develop algorithms that use weather conditions, system operator forecast plans, and price forecasts as inputs to predict curtailment events. The expected outcome is a more precise wind power forecast, enabling better decision-making for system operators and traders.
summaries.Simulation of artefacts caused by 3D cap: This project proposes developing algorithms to simulate 3D scanning artifacts (noise, occlusion, clutter) on existing 3D meshes. The goal is to create a scalable and cost-effective benchmark for evaluating 3D shape matching algorithms used in applications like self-driving cars. By simulating artifacts from techniques like LiDAR and photogrammetry, the project aims to provide a controlled environment for testing matching algorithms under various conditions, isolating the impact of individual artifacts.
summaries.Semantic Text Indexing: This project explores semantic text indexing to improve information retrieval at scale. It aims to develop alternative methods to deep learning (e.g., word2vec) for endowing text with semantics. The research will focus on semantic text matching across large document collections, addressing the limitations of current deep learning approaches in terms of scalability and interpretability. The expected outcome is a novel and scalable approach to semantic text indexing, enhancing the accuracy and efficiency of information retrieval systems.
summaries.Merging of offline databases: This project explores solutions for merging offline databases, focusing on scenarios like rescue teams needing to synchronize data in disconnected environments. It will investigate and compare techniques such as Conflict-free Replicated Data Types (CRDTs), mergeable data structures, and operational transformations. The expected outcome is an evaluation of these methods and potentially a proposed solution for efficient and reliable offline database merging.
summaries.Open-ended evolution: This project explores open-ended evolution, aiming to replicate the endless creation of novel organisms seen in nature. It builds upon the Paired Open-Ended Trailblazer (POET) algorithm and its recent hybrid with Neuroevolution of Augmented Topologies (NEAT). The project involves either extending the existing hybrid algorithm or investigating alternative algorithmic approaches to open-ended evolution. Expected outcomes include advancements in understanding and implementing open-ended evolution, potentially leading to more creative and adaptive AI systems.
summaries.Managing big data volumes: This project explores methods for parallel insertion of large data volumes, potentially focusing on specific applications like geographic satellite data. It investigates efficient parallel insertion into traditional tree structures such as B-trees and R-trees, as well as handling sequential data like logs. The research aims to address the scalability limitations of parallel databases with shared logs, with potential applications in storing GPS trajectories. The expected outcome is a better understanding of parallel data insertion techniques and their applicability to big data management.
summaries.Numerical Contours: This project focuses on developing a scalable annotation system for temporal and numerical expressions within large document collections, such as Wikipedia. The research will address annotating numerical quantities associated with entities, modeling units for easy conversions, and ensuring scalability. The project will leverage techniques from databases, information retrieval, and natural language processing to achieve these goals. The expected outcome is a functional annotator capable of processing large volumes of text and accurately extracting and representing numerical data.
summaries.Merging of spatial data: This project explores efficient merging techniques for spatial data indexed by space-filling curves, analogous to LSM-trees used for key-based data. The research will investigate methods to handle high insertion rates in geodata by adapting merging strategies from LSM-trees to spatial data structures like R-trees. The expected outcome is a novel approach for merging spatial data that improves performance in big data scenarios.
summaries.Hybrid Vector Search in High-Dimensional: This project explores hybrid vector search in high-dimensional spaces, aiming to improve upon existing solutions from the 2024 SIGMOD Programming Contest. It involves building an index to efficiently find approximate k-nearest neighbors based on vector similarity while satisfying constraints on non-vector attributes. The project will analyze and enhance top-performing contest algorithms using more sophisticated indexing techniques and extend them to accommodate diverse attribute and query types. The expected outcome is a hybrid vector search index with improved query performance and broader applicability.
summaries.Locality of Access in Graph Databases: This project investigates graph ordering schemes to improve data locality for graph queries, focusing on minimizing cache misses in scenarios where only a portion of the graph is accessed. It aims to implement and evaluate existing and potentially new graph ordering techniques, particularly at the disk level, using a benchmark based on real graph query workloads. The project may utilize graph database systems like Kùzu and requires knowledge of database internals and C/C++ programming. Expected outcomes include a comparative analysis of graph ordering schemes and insights into their effectiveness for various query types.
summaries.Particle Swarm Optimisation as a modelli: This project explores Particle Swarm Optimisation (PSO) as a modeling tool for climate change, focusing on individual behavior and contributions to benefit future populations. The research aims to develop a PSO modeling environment to study how individuals can be incentivized to increase their contribution/sacrifice in addressing climate change. The expected outcome is a functional PSO model capable of simulating and analyzing societal behaviors related to climate action.
summaries.Learned index and updates: This project investigates update handling in learned indexes, aiming to improve performance under high insert/update loads. It will survey existing techniques and propose enhancements. Additionally, the project explores learned multi-dimensional indexes, potentially focusing on the challenges of indexing string data. The expected outcome is a better understanding of update strategies for learned indexes and potential advancements in learned multi-dimensional indexing.
summaries.Similarity of trajectories: This project explores algorithms for trajectory similarity, applicable to ride-sharing, route identification, and Strava segments. The research focuses on developing an efficient index to pre-process trajectory data before applying computationally intensive similarity algorithms like Dynamic Time Warping. Building upon previous work with Locality Sensitive Hashing (LSH), the project aims to optimize parameters for various trajectory datasets to improve the efficiency and accuracy of trajectory similarity identification. The expected outcome is a practical indexing method that enhances the performance of trajectory similarity searches.
summaries.MySQL related projects 2025: This master's project explores implementation and evaluation opportunities within MySQL, in collaboration with MySQL Engineering at Oracle Trondheim. Specific topics will be determined through discussion. The project requires strong programming skills, an interest in algorithms, and prior knowledge from courses like TDT4150. The expected outcome is a practical implementation and evaluation of a chosen MySQL-related feature or optimization.
summaries.Learning Indexing Patterns from Annotate: This project explores indexing annotated document collections to improve information retrieval based on entities, temporal expressions, and numerical ranges. Leveraging NLP tools like Stanford CoreNLP, the research will analyze how semantic annotations in queries (e.g., "tokyo olympics") can inform indexing strategies. The goal is to enable efficient selection of relevant documents based on specific time periods, entity categories, and numerical ranges, drawing from databases, information retrieval, data mining, and NLP techniques.
summaries.Industry (and AI-lab pitched) project pr: This project explores various industry-driven applications of Visual Intelligence (AI/CV). It encompasses projects from MIA Health (digital twins), Rosenborg (football video analysis), Jotun (fouling analysis), Hydro (grain size characterization), St. Olavs/NTNU (coronary artery labeling), SINTEF/SVV (autonomous driving in Nordic conditions), Kartverket (aerial lidar classification), Proxpect Drones (drone inspection), and lobster handling in the food industry. The projects utilize AI and computer vision techniques for detection, tracking, segmentation, and classification, leveraging video, lidar, and image data. Expected outcomes include improved healthcare diagnostics, sports analytics, material analysis, autonomous navigation, and food handling processes.
summaries.AI-based computer vision for salmon iden: This project explores AI-based computer vision for either salmon identification/tracking or perception systems for autonomous ships. The pre-project focuses on literature review and technical background research for both potential MSc project directions. The primary outcome is acquiring necessary knowledge and developing a detailed research plan for the subsequent MSc project, based on the chosen topic.
summaries.AD - AI-agents trained end-to-end by Imi: This project explores training AI agents for autonomous driving using deep reinforcement learning and imitation learning in simulated environments like CARLA, NVIDIA Omniverse, and MARS. The research will investigate state-of-the-art approaches such as UniAD and MILE, and leverage real-world data by creating a virtual replica of the campus area for training. The expected outcome is the development of AI agents capable of navigating complex simulated environments, with potential applications in autonomous driving systems.
summaries.[2023/2024] Exploring the Effectiveness: This project explores synthetic data generation effectiveness in Air Traffic Management (ATM) using GANs, VAEs, and diffusion models. It evaluates synthetic data quality and its impact on machine learning models for turnaround time, flight delay, and passenger flow prediction. Addressing challenges like mixed data types and missing values, the research aims to improve ATM efficiency, robustness, and resilience through AI adoption. Expected outcomes include insights into synthetic data's ability to overcome data limitations and accelerate AI adoption in ATM.
summaries.Aneo: Ensambles for probabilistic foreca: This project explores probabilistic wind power forecasting using ensemble weather forecasts as input. The goal is to improve forecast accuracy and estimate uncertainty in wind power production for Aneo's 11 wind farms. The project involves data preparation, building machine learning models, conducting experiments to evaluate model performance, and analyzing results. The expected outcome is a methodology for utilizing weather ensembles to enhance wind power forecasting and improve profitability.
summaries.[NorwAI] Automatic Reading of Traffic An: This project aims to develop an automatic system for reading traffic announcements for public broadcast in Sweden, utilizing speech recognition and text-to-speech technologies. The system will process traffic announcements from NRK, converting them into synthesized speech for timely and reliable dissemination. The expected outcome is an accurate and fast system that improves road safety by ensuring critical messages reach all users, regardless of radio usage. The project addresses the risk of misinterpretation to enhance driving safety and transportation management.
summaries.Applying ChatGPT for Data Integration: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) like ChatGPT for data integration from heterogeneous sources. It will focus on prompt engineering and fine-tuning LLMs, comparing the performance of the LLM-based approach against traditional data integration methods. The project aims to assess the potential and risks of using LLMs for data integration, with a proof-of-concept implementation as the expected outcome.
summaries.Anomaly detection in x-rays: This project focuses on developing a deep learning model for anomaly detection and localization in chest X-rays using the VinDR dataset. The model will differentiate between normal and abnormal X-rays, localize the abnormal regions, and classify the type of anomaly into one of fourteen conditions. The project involves experimenting with various CNN-based deep learning architectures to achieve these objectives.
summaries.AI-Powered Processing of Public Consulta: This project explores using AI to automate the processing of public consultation responses for Oslo Municipality. It aims to develop an AI pipeline using Large Language Models (LLMs) for categorization, clustering, and summarization of textual feedback. The project will compare the AI pipeline's performance against manual analysis in terms of quality and speed, utilizing a municipality-provided dataset for fine-tuning. Expected outcomes include a proof-of-concept pipeline and an assessment of AI's potential to improve efficiency and reduce bias in public consultation analysis.
summaries.[Collaboration with Maritime Robotics] O: This project focuses on optimizing the RTMDet object detection model for real-time performance on the NVIDIA AGX Orin platform, targeting Maritime Robotics' SeaSight pipeline. The research will explore techniques like model quantization, pruning, and GPU/DLA offloading using TensorRT and CUDA. The goal is to achieve real-time inference with minimal energy consumption, integrating the optimized model into SeaSight to enhance situational awareness for USV operators. Expected outcomes include an optimized RTMDet implementation and a set of tailored optimization techniques for the Orin platform.
summaries.[Collaboration with Maritime Robotics] E: This project explores efficient Vision Transformers (ViTs) for real-time object segmentation on the NVIDIA AGX Orin, in collaboration with Maritime Robotics. It focuses on transformer-specific optimizations like sparse attention, token reduction, and mixed-precision quantization to improve speed, power efficiency, and accuracy. The research will benchmark optimized ViT models against baseline implementations and CNN-based methods, aiming for seamless integration into the SeaSight system. Expected outcomes include optimized ViT implementations for real-time inference and a comparative framework for ViT and CNN deployment in maritime surveillance.
summaries.Aneo: Predictive maintenance of cooling: This project focuses on predictive maintenance of retail cooling systems using historical event data (faults, maintenance) and sensor measurements (temperature, pressure, energy consumption) provided by Aneo. The goal is to build models that predict future faults and time until failure, enabling optimized maintenance scheduling and reduced service costs. The project involves data preparation, model building, experimentation, and results analysis, utilizing cloud infrastructure provided by Aneo. Expected outcomes include validated predictive models for fault prediction in cooling systems.
summaries.Causal Inference for Headaches: This project explores causal inference techniques to identify causes and effective remedies for headaches using patient data. It involves constructing a causal graph based on expert knowledge and estimating the effects of variables on headache occurrence and pain reduction. The project utilizes AI, probability theory, and probabilistic programming. Expected outcomes include a causal model of headaches and insights into potential treatments.
summaries.AI-powered Data Extraction from Archival: This project explores using AI, specifically Large Language Models and image recognition, to improve the digital accessibility of historical records at the National Archives. The research will focus on a specific data source provided by the Archives, such as handwritten documents or pre-19th century records. The expected outcome is a method for enhanced data extraction and accessibility, evaluated in collaboration with experts from the National Archives.
summaries.Bloom's learning outcomes classification: This project investigates the potential of Large Language Models (LLMs) for classifying course learning objectives according to Bloom's Taxonomy (remember, understand, apply, analyze, evaluate, create). It aims to design a model to classify course descriptions and learning objectives into Bloom's levels and compare its performance against existing LLMs. The project will utilize Python and require skills in machine learning, deep learning, and prompt engineering. The expected outcome is a comparative analysis of LLMs' effectiveness in Bloom's Taxonomy classification.
summaries.Artificial Intelligence and Machine Lear: This project explores AI/ML applications in geophysics, leveraging high-performance computing for analyzing large datasets from IoT sensors like Distributed Acoustic Sensing. The research focuses on developing new algorithms for processing geophysical data, with potential applications in understanding sustainability issues like landslides and CO2 storage. Building upon existing models for air quality and soil moisture prediction, the project aims to improve forecasting in complex spatio-temporal settings, emphasizing spatial and seasonal generalizability, explainability, and interpretability. The project is connected to NTNU's Center for Geophysical Forecasting, providing access to data and collaboration with experienced researchers.
summaries.Aneo: Why do wind turbines fail?: This project aims to automate root-cause analysis of premature failures in Aneo's wind turbines, focusing on bushings, bearings, and gearboxes. It involves analyzing vibration and SCADA data to identify failure indicators. The research will explore existing methods and algorithms for root cause analysis, implementing and testing selected approaches to automate the process. The expected outcome is a system that supports maintenance decision-making by automatically identifying the root causes of wind turbine failures.
summaries.Bio-Inspired Artificial Intelligence for: This project explores bio-inspired AI and evolutionary algorithms to automatically generate engaging character mechanics for the SOL action game. It focuses on generating and evaluating characters based on their "interestingness" and "fun" factor using techniques like novelty search and adaptive stress testing. The research aims to study alternative diversity preservation Genetic Algorithms, formulate character goals using multi-objective GAs, and develop a mixed-initiative approach involving human designers. The expected outcome is an AI system capable of generating compelling game characters, with insights applicable to other simulation environments.
summaries.Application of artificial intelligence-b: This project focuses on developing an AI-based image soft-sensor to automate and improve the analysis of high-temperature material properties using images/videos from sessile drop experiments. The research involves data pre-processing, labeling datasets with expert input, and implementing a deep learning model for image analysis. Expected outcomes include a functional soft-sensor integrated with lab equipment, enabling efficient and accurate evaluation of material behavior at high temperatures, specifically wetting, softening, and melting kinetics.
summaries.Anomaly detection using foundational tim: This project explores anomaly detection in time series data using foundational time-series models like Lag-Llama and TimesFM. The research aims to leverage the zero and few-shot capabilities of these models to develop an anomaly detection system applicable to real-world data. The project involves understanding the state-of-the-art anomaly detection techniques and then implementing and testing the new system. The expected outcome is a zero or few-shot anomaly detection system validated on real-life datasets.
summaries.Automated Single-Cell Type Annotation fo: This project aims to develop an automated machine-learning tool for single-cell type annotation in salmon genomic samples to aid in preventing salmon skin disease. The project will utilize Python and machine learning libraries to expedite the annotation process, currently a bottleneck in genomic analysis. Expected outcomes include a functional tool for predicting single-cell types, enhanced understanding of aquaculture practices, and development of expertise in machine learning and bioinformatics. The project offers experience in data analysis, algorithm development, and collaboration within an international team.
summaries.Evaluating quantizations of large langua: This project evaluates the effectiveness of different quantization methods for large language models (LLMs) on edge systems. It focuses on assessing the trade-offs between quantization overhead, accuracy, and responsiveness. The research will involve implementing and testing various quantization techniques on a target edge platform like Nvidia Jetson TX2. The expected outcome is a comparative analysis of quantization methods, providing insights into their suitability for deploying LLMs on resource-constrained edge devices.
summaries.Computational Musical Creativity: This project explores computational musical creativity, focusing on using computers as creative agents in music composition and lyric generation. It encompasses various approaches, including rule-based systems, stochastic methods, neural networks, and evolutionary algorithms. Potential research areas include composing music in specific styles, identifying musical keys/moods, generating lyrics, music information retrieval, or automatic music transcription. The expected outcome is a deeper understanding and implementation of computational techniques for enhancing or automating musical creativity.
summaries.Digital Forensics: This digital forensics project explores using writing style to identify author characteristics, detect plagiarism, and uncover social media misuse. It focuses on author profiling (age, gender, bot detection) and identification, and plagiarism detection. The expected outcome is a system capable of analyzing text to deduce author attributes and identify potential instances of plagiarism or misuse.
summaries.Comparing Synthetic to Real Alignment Da: This project investigates the effectiveness of synthetic data versus real data for aligning Norwegian Large Language Models (LLMs), addressing the challenge of data scarcity. It will compare synthetic and real data using models from the TrustLLM and NorLLM projects, employing both qualitative and quantitative evaluation methods. The goal is to determine if synthetic data can compensate for a lack of real alignment data, contributing to the ongoing debate about AI's ability to overcome data limitations.
summaries.Computational Creative Artform Transitio: This project explores computational creativity by investigating transitions between different creative art forms. It focuses on generating one art form (e.g., music, images, text) from another, leveraging techniques similar to Stable Diffusion. The research aims to contribute to the production, understanding, or evaluation of creativity through computer systems, potentially supporting human creativity in diverse fields like language, design, and music. The expected outcome is a system capable of transforming one art form into another, demonstrating computational creativity.
summaries.Customized Master Projects in Basic Mach: This master's project focuses on foundational machine learning research, offering students customized thesis projects in areas like algorithm development (supervised, unsupervised, reinforcement learning), theoretical investigations, and research into model robustness, explainability, fairness, or optimization. Students will work alongside experienced researchers, gaining hands-on experience and contributing to advancements in ML. The expected outcome is a refined research topic aligned with the student's interests and the team's ongoing work, leading to a valuable contribution to the field.
summaries.Cool AI: This project focuses on exploring a "cool" and difficult problem or method within the field of Artificial Intelligence. The specific research area and technologies will be determined based on the chosen problem. The expected outcome is a novel contribution to AI, demonstrating a solution to the selected challenge.
summaries.Dense Monocular Depth Estimation for Unm: This project focuses on developing a real-time monocular depth estimation model for Unmanned Surface Vessels (USVs), suitable for embedded platforms like Jetson Orin NX. It will explore distilling the Depth Anything model into a smaller, YOLO-based model and calibrating depth estimates using LIDAR and/or AIS data, without human annotation. The final system will be integrated into Maritime Robotics' SeaSight system and tested on the water. The expected outcome is an improved situational awareness system for autonomous USV navigation.
summaries.Computational Linguistic Creativity: This project explores computational linguistic creativity, focusing on developing systems that either exhibit creativity or analyze it. Potential research areas include generating poetry, screenplays, song lyrics, analogies, and metaphors. Alternatively, the project could focus on understanding creativity through sarcasm detection, humor comprehension, or rhyme interpretation. Specific tasks could involve generating and evaluating computational poetry, translating jokes between languages, or generating plot twists in movies. The expected outcome is a system or analysis that contributes to the understanding or generation of creative language.
summaries.Computational nanosystems: Toward real w: This project explores artificial spin ice (ASI) within the reservoir computing framework for real-world tasks like MNIST and spoken digit recognition. Using the Flatspin simulator, the research will focus on optimizing input encoding, designing ASI reservoirs with sufficient computational power, and developing effective readout strategies. The project aims to bridge theoretical findings with practical applications, contributing to the SOCRATES and SpinENGIN projects that investigate nanomagnet ensembles as a novel computational substrate. Expected outcomes include demonstrating the feasibility of ASI reservoirs for specific tasks and advancing the understanding of material computation.
summaries.E-Assessment in Higher Education with th: This project evaluates the performance of LLMs (ChatGPT, Palm, LLaMA, Mistral) in e-assessment. It involves training LLMs on course content (e.g., BS Computer Science) and using prompt engineering to generate question papers with varying difficulty levels and formats. The project will assess the LLMs' ability to score student responses and provide descriptive feedback. The goal is to determine the capabilities of different foundational models in e-assessment and the impact of fine-tuning. Python will be used, requiring skills in machine learning, deep learning, and prompt engineering.
summaries.Control and monitoring of robots through: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) to improve robot control through natural language. The research focuses on developing an LLM-based model that translates natural language instructions into formal mission specifications in Planning Domain Definition Language (PDDL). The expected outcome is a system that enables more intuitive robot programming and control, particularly for multi-robot missions. The project involves testing the developed models on physical robots at SINTEF's lab.
summaries.Context-Aware Decoding using Multi-Lingu: This project focuses on improving automated metadata generation for Norwegian language technology, leveraging language models during Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR). It aims to enhance access to and utilization of transcribed speech data, particularly for conversational speech. The project will utilize resources like the ParlaMint-NO corpus and contribute to advancements in ASR and Machine Learning for under-resourced languages. Expected outcomes include improved metadata quality, strengthened Norwegian language technology, and broad dissemination of research findings.
summaries.Dive into how models for animal classifi: This project explores animal classification and detection models, focusing on understanding their internal mechanisms for fine-tuning and improving localization. It aims to enhance precision in dynamic environments, such as underwater settings with "foggy conditions," using techniques like synthetic data and augmentation. The research will concentrate on fish classification, object detection, and re-identification, with the goal of transferring findings to general animal detection. The project utilizes Python and requires skills in machine learning, deep learning, and object detection/localization models. Expected outcomes include improved model understanding, enhanced precision, and solutions for identification issues in challenging environments.
summaries.Evolutionary Algorithms with Application: This project explores the theory and application of evolutionary algorithms (EAs), focusing on improving EAs for specific applications by combining heuristics and adaptive methods, potentially incorporating concepts from stochastic local search. It investigates using Markov chain analysis and high-performance computing to enhance EA-based machine learning for massive datasets while reducing computational costs. The project also aims to bridge the gap between the theory of parametric Markov chains and AI/ML communities, particularly in the context of trustworthy AI.
summaries.Detecting Social Media Risk Users: This project explores using machine learning to identify at-risk users on social media. Focusing on mental health issues, radicalization, and targeting by predators, the research will apply various machine learning techniques, potentially including deep learning, to social media text data. The expected outcome is a model capable of detecting users exhibiting signs of risk, contributing to mental health support and security efforts. Data gathering will be a key component, utilizing existing datasets or creating a new one.
summaries.Cross-Lingual Sentence Simplification wi: This project explores cross-lingual sentence simplification using Large Language Models (LLMs). It aims to simplify complex sentences in one language into simpler sentences in another, preserving meaning. The project will involve fine-tuning LLMs on monolingual simplification datasets and parallel corpora with one-to-many and many-to-one sentence alignments. Evaluation will be performed using NorLLM and TrustLLM, benchmarking against state-of-the-art models. The expected outcome is a system capable of effective cross-lingual sentence simplification, potentially improving machine translation by addressing sentence length variations.
summaries.Computational Creativity in Art, Images: This project explores computational creativity in art, images, or videos, focusing on systems that generate novel and meaningful content. It encompasses creative computer programs, systems recognizing creativity, and tools assisting human creativity. Potential research areas include developing systems like "The Painting Fool" or exploring text-to-art generation (e.g., Stable Diffusion), image-to-music conversion, or automatic image/video captioning. The expected outcome is a deeper understanding of computational creativity and the development of innovative systems in the chosen area.
summaries.Computer Vision in Bad Weather condition: This project explores computer vision techniques for autonomous driving in adverse weather conditions like rain and snow, focusing on robust object detection (vehicles, road markings, obstacles). It will investigate combining machine learning and classical computer vision to develop algorithms that account for image degradation caused by weather. The project will utilize an existing "bad weather driving" database and may involve collaboration with an industry partner, potentially including a research stay in Germany. Expected outcomes include novel algorithms for improved visual perception and distance estimation in challenging visibility.
summaries.Computational Creativity with Reinforcem: This project explores computational creativity using reinforcement learning (RL) and generative adversarial networks (GANs). It aims to apply RL, potentially with human feedback, to creative tasks like art, music, or language generation, expanding beyond its current use in systems like ChatGPT. The project may also investigate integrating RL with GANs, primarily explored in image generation, to enhance creative output. The expected outcome is a novel creative system leveraging RL and/or GANs.
summaries.FACIAL DATA PROCESSING USING ZOOM SDK: This project explores facial data processing using the Zoom SDK. It involves developing facial processing tools utilizing raw image data from the Zoom platform. The project requires knowledge of Linux, Python, and C/C++, and builds upon concepts from visual computing and graphics courses. Expected outcomes include functional facial processing tools integrated with the Zoom SDK.
summaries.Human-Machine Symbiosis: How does decisi: This project investigates how big data analytics impacts human decision-making, focusing on cognitive overload and biases that hinder insight adoption. In collaboration with the Big Data Observatory, the research will involve designing a study protocol and collecting neurophysiological data (eye-tracking and EEG) from participants. The goal is to understand how individuals process and integrate data-driven insights, ultimately informing strategies to improve human-machine symbiosis in decision-making contexts.
summaries.Federated Learning for Privacy-Preservin: This project explores federated learning for privacy-preserving medical image analysis. It aims to develop a collaborative machine learning model for tasks like disease diagnosis and anomaly detection without centralizing sensitive patient data. The project focuses on training a shared model across multiple medical institutions, exchanging only model updates to maintain data privacy and minimize the risk of data breaches. The expected outcome is a robust and accurate medical image analysis system that adheres to strict privacy standards.
summaries.Identifying Online Hate Speech and Cyber: This project investigates machine learning methods for identifying hate speech and cyberbullying in online user-generated content. It will analyze existing flame-annotated datasets from platforms like chat rooms, online games, Wikipedia, and Twitter. The research aims to improve the speed and accuracy of hate speech detection, addressing the limitations of current manual moderation approaches used by social media sites and other organizations.
summaries.Generating simulations that match data ​: This project explores simulation-based inference for hybrid AI, combining machine learning and physical knowledge. It focuses on using machine learning to approximate likelihood functions for Bayesian inference in stochastic models. The project can be applied, aiming to accelerate model identification and quantify uncertainty using commercial simulation software and real data from wind turbines and compressors, or theoretical, studying machine learning models for probability distributions under physical constraints. The project will utilize public and proprietary data and involves probability density estimation, Bayesian inference, stochastic differential equations, and uncertainty quantification.
summaries.From Interview Transcription to Article: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate article drafting from interview transcriptions. The research involves fine-tuning models like GPT, Llama, Mistral, Gemini, or DeepSeek on a dataset of Norwegian interviews and articles from Adressavisen. The primary goal is to develop an AI capable of summarizing key messages and generating article drafts. Journalists will evaluate the quality of the generated drafts in a user study.
summaries.Generative AI for Meta Data Inference (w: This project focuses on using generative AI to infer missing metadata in large document archives, specifically for DNB. The project involves building an NLP pipeline to process documents, applying machine learning methods to estimate missing metadata (e.g., document type, product references), and creating a reference dataset. Expected outcomes include a functional system for metadata inference and a demonstration of its effectiveness on DNB's document archive. The student may have the opportunity to intern at DNB.
summaries.LLMs for Maritime language: This project explores the application of Large Language Models (LLMs) to the maritime domain. It investigates fine-tuning, continued pre-training, and Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) techniques using maritime-specific documents. The goal is to optimize LLMs for maritime language use cases, such as question answering related to maritime regulations. The project will be co-supervised by Børge Rokseth and Rudolf Mester.
summaries.Improved Ambulance Response: Prediction: This project focuses on predicting future emergency events to improve ambulance response times in Oslo, Norway. It will utilize a dataset of historical ambulance missions linked to sociodemographic, traffic, weather, and event data. The goal is to predict the number of events and case load in specific geographical locations. Technologies involved include machine learning and time series analysis. The expected outcome is a model that can forecast future ambulance demand, enabling better resource allocation and potentially faster response times.
summaries.Machine Learning for Black-box Safety Va: This project explores using machine learning, specifically Adaptive Stress Testing (AST) with reinforcement learning (RL), to enhance the safety validation of Zeabuz's autonomous marine vessels. The research will leverage a digital twin of the milliAmpere 2 ferry to simulate various operational scenarios. The goal is to identify potential system weaknesses and failure modes through intelligent scenario design and analysis, potentially extending AST algorithms with multi-objective RL or uncertainty estimation techniques. Expected outcomes include a validated AST system and improved safety assessment methods for autonomous ferries.
summaries.Exploring the design space of convolutio: This project explores the design space of convolutional neural networks (CNNs) on edge systems, specifically Nvidia Jetson, considering width, depth, and resolution. It investigates the impact of these dimensions on accuracy, energy efficiency, and latency. The goal is to define an effective design space for CNNs on edge devices and gain insights for designing efficient CNNs tailored for resource-constrained edge environments.
summaries.Improved Ambulance Response: Optimizatio: This project aims to optimize ambulance resource placement to improve response times. Utilizing a dataset from Oslo's EMCC, the research will analyze historical mission data, sociodemographic factors, traffic, and weather to dynamically allocate ambulances based on predicted demand. The project will leverage optimization techniques to balance workload and contingency, considering time of day, season, and location. The expected outcome is a model for improved ambulance deployment strategies, leading to faster response intervals for emergency calls.
summaries.Language Technology and Large Language M: This project explores language technology, focusing on large language models (LLMs) like GPT and LLaMA, for both English and Norwegian. It aims to address limitations in applying language technology to resource-constrained languages like Norwegian. The project involves literature review, framework selection, and application in areas like dialogue generation or chatbots, potentially using datasets from DNB or open sources. Expected outcomes include evaluating the performance of LLMs in chosen applications and providing insights for improving and automating internal processes.
summaries.Explaining AI-based Recommendations (wit: This project explores Explainable AI (XAI) methods to understand AI-driven recommendations in banking. Using a large dataset from Sparebank 1 SMN, the student will analyze complex models' outputs to provide explanations for product recommendations. The research aims to enhance the transparency of AI systems, enabling employees to understand the reasoning behind suggestions. The project will be supervised by Stian Arntsen (Sparebank 1 SMN) and Inga Strümke (NTNU).
summaries.Machine Learning for Integrating Visual: This project explores machine learning for integrating visual and language intelligence, focusing on either image captioning or multimodal named entity recognition. The image captioning track investigates data augmentation techniques, particularly paraphrasing, to improve caption quality using deep learning models and datasets like MS COCO and potentially Norwegian language data. The multimodal NER track focuses on combining textual and image data for enhanced entity extraction. Expected outcomes include improved machine learning models, novel data augmentation methods, and enhanced image captioning metrics. Technologies include deep learning, network architecture search, and pre-trained embeddings.
summaries.Graphics Content Generation for Ad Campa: This project explores using Large Language Models (LLMs) to automate graphic content generation for ad campaigns, addressing the scarcity and workload of graphic designers.
